On review of past medical history  the patient has been a long-term smoker for the past 40 years and is also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  both of which are managed with appropriate medications without recent changes nor complications. His family history reveals that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 62.   The patient lives with his wife in an urban setting  consumes a diet high in saturated fats  and leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle with little to no physical exercise. These factors contribute further to his increased risk of coronary heart disease. Patient is adherent to prescribed medication regimen and follows up regularly with his primary care provider. His last physical examination  around 6 months ago  was significant for elevated blood pressure. The patient's ECG at presentation shows ST-segment elevations in anterior leads  concerning for anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.   This population mirror's the literature's highest risk demographic  given the patient's race  age  and predisposing factors including poorly controlled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  a strong family history  and a history of smoking.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Garcia  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that started an hour ago and radiates to the left arm and jaw. The pain is associated with feelings of tightness in the chest  shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He rates the pain an ""8"" out of 10 and states it's unrelieved by rest. He further mentions this is the first time he has experienced such symptoms.  His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension which are managed with Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. He is a retired truck driver and admits to a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He also enjoys drinking alcohol occasionally and has a BMI of 29.5.  On further inquiry  he shares that his father had a heart attack at the age of 70. Mr. Garcia has been non-compliant with his medications in the past few months due to economic difficulties and increased stress levels because of the recent death of his wife.   This script represents an average patient suffering from acute myocardial infarction  based on demographics found in literature. Older males  especially with a background of hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  obesity  stress  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  are at a significantly high risk of developing this condition.

A 60-year-old African-American male named John Smith presents to the emergency department (ED) with severe crushing chest pain that started an hour ago. He describes it as a severe pressure sensation in his chest and rates it as an 8 out of 10 in severity. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw  and it is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and sweatiness.   Mr. Smith is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which have been poorly controlled over the past year. He has been non-compliant with his prescribed medications. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking tobacco  reports a high intake of fatty foods and admits to a sedentary lifestyle.  His father had premature coronary artery disease and a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years.  Mr. Smith appears to be anxious  his skin is pale and clammy  and looks to be in distress. His current vital signs are: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per minute; arterial oxygen saturation 92% on room air; and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute.  On physical examination  he has clear lung fields auscultation but tachycardia with no additional heart sounds or murmurs on cardiac auscultation. He has no lower limb swelling.  Given the typical nature of his chest pain  associated symptoms  relevant risk factors including his demographic details and past medical history  a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is strongly considered. Immediate ECG and cardiac enzymes are requested as part of his assessment and management in the ED.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Both conditions have been managed poorly due to inconsistent adherence to dietary restrictions and medication schedules. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but has a cumulative history of 30-pack-years. He does not consume alcohol and denies any illegal substance use. He reports a family history of heart disease  with his father having suffered a similar cardiac event at the age of 70.   John presents to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden  severe chest pain radiating down his left arm. He describes the pain as a ""heavy"" and ""crushing"" sensation in the center of his chest. The pain started approximately three hours ago while he was doing his usual morning walk. Associated symptoms include cold sweats  shortness of breath  and nausea. He has concurred that the severity of pain has progressively increased since onset  and was unaffected by rest or over the counter medications.  On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. His initial vital signs are as follows: blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse 98 beats per minute  respirations 22 breaths per minute  and O2 saturation 95% on room air.  Of note  he had an EKG 6 months back for a routine physical examination which was normal. Current troponin levels have been ordered. John has been informed about the potential implications of these symptoms  and the necessary steps toward immediate management of this possible life-threatening condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Hernandez is a 63-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and lightheadedness. The pain started approximately 45 minutes ago while he was mowing the lawn and has not subsided with rest. Mr. Hernandez describes the pain as ""crushing"" and rates it as an 8 on a scale of 0-10. His vital signs on arrival are blood pressure 160/90mmHg  pulse rate 90 bpm  respiratory rate 18 bpm  temperature 99 degrees Fahrenheit  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air.  On physical examination  Mr. Hernandez appears in distress with pallor and is diaphoretic. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His breath sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.  Mr. Hernandez has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a 40-pack-year smoker but denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His current medications are metformin  atorvastatin  and amlodipine. His family history is significant for a father who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   An EKG performed in the emergency department shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior chest leads (V1-V4)  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.   Given the patient's symptoms  medical history  physical examination findings  and EKG results  the clinical team initiates immediate management for ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that began one hour ago. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath  light-headedness  and diaphoresis. He rates his pain as 10/10 and says that it is unrelieved by rest. The patient has a known past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a smoker with 40 pack-years history and his father died of a heart attack at the age of 55. He says he hasn't been managing his medications and lifestyle well due to work stress. His medication regimen includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Davis  a 60-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe substernal chest pain  radiating to his left arm. He describes the pain as a 'crushing' sensation  accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. The symptoms began approximately 2 hours ago while he was at rest  and they have persisted despite his attempt to alleviate the pain through rest and nitroglycerin use at home.   Relevant past medical history reveals that Mr. Davis is a chronic smoker for 30 years and a diagnosed hypertensive patient for the last 5 years. His father died of coronary artery disease at age 62. He does not have a history of diabetes mellitus. He is currently taking antihypertensive medications  inclusive of a beta-blocker and thiazide diuretic  but he admits he sometimes forgets to take his medications regularly.   No known allergies are reported.   He works as a courier and admits that his lifestyle is predominantly sedentary  frequently eating fast food and rarely exercising. A review of his recent lipid profile shows a slightly high LDL cholesterol levels with a value of 145 mg/dl  a low HDL cholesterol of 35 mg/dL  and a total cholesterol of 210 mg/dL.   These details suggest that Mr. Davis is at high risk for acute myocardial infarction due to his ethnicity  age  male gender  family history of heart disease  personal past medical history of hypertension  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  unhealthy diet  and irregular medication compliance.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Jacobs  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe  constant  central chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. He describes it as a squeezing and heavy pain  rating it 10 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain started while he was gardening and has not relieved despite rest. Associated symptoms include sweating  nausea  shortness of breath and a sense of impending doom.   Upon further inquiry  patient admits to a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He also has a 40 pack year smoking history. Genetic history is significant with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. He admits to non-compliance with his prescribed medications  including Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  and has not been entirely adherent to lifestyle modifications such as a low-sodium and low-cholesterol diet  recommended by his primary care physician. Furthermore  patient reports a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. He also has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. The patient denies any illegal drug use. There is no reported history of allergies.  With this kind of clinical presentation  the history of risk factors  as well as the demographics (male  older age  African American race  family history)  an acute myocardial infarction is highly suspected. Mr. Jacobs's age and racial background are particularly noteworthy since African American men are statistically at a higher risk for heart conditions.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old African American male comes into the emergency department  escorted by his wife  complaining of chest pain radiating to his left arm and neck. The pain is severe  and he describes it as ""a heavy pressure""  consistently rated at 8/10. The discomfort started roughly an hour ago while he was at home relaxing after dinner  and has not subsided. He also reports feeling short of breath  nauseous  and noticeably diaphoretic. He admits to feeling lightheaded but denies any loss of consciousness. There are no other associated symptoms.  He is a known patient with uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which he takes metformin  atorvastatin  and hydrochlorothiazide respectively but has been non-compliant with medications due to financial constraints. Until recently  he has been a cigarette smoker with a 30 pack-year history but had quit 6 months ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally  usually reserved for social celebrations. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  His vitals on presenting are: BP 160/90 mmHg  HR 100 bpm  RR 16 breaths/min  Temp 98.6°F  O2 Sat 93% on room air. The patient appears visibly uncomfortable  sweating profusely.  Given the history  accompanied symptoms  and high-risk factors present  an acute myocardial infarction is highly suspected. Immediate EKG is being obtained and cardiac enzymes are ordered. Plans for starting on aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen therapy are underway.   This case is consistent with the demographic groups that have higher rates of cardiovascular disease  including myocardial infarction  and hypertension. African American males are especially at high risk  along with individuals with a history of tobacco smoking and those who have primary relatives with a history of heart disease.

Patient Presentation: A 62-year old African American man presents to the emergency department with central crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm. The pain started 2 hours ago  while he was at rest  and is associated with profuse sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. He rates the pain as a 10 out of 10  and characterizes it as ""the worst pain he has ever felt.""  Demographics: The patient is a retired construction worker. He is a widower and lives alone in a city-center apartment. He also has a son living across town who visits a few times a month. He has a long history of smoking about 20 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both are controlled through oral medications. He is overweight with a BMI of 30.8. He has been previously admitted once due to angina pectoris approximately two years ago.  In his family history  his father died of heart disease at the age of 70. The patient has been asked to attend cardiac rehabilitation programs before  following his previous episode of chest pain  but has been non-compliant thus far.   He is currently on medications: Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Aspirin for previous heart disease. Despite these measures  his risk factors are not fully controlled  indicated by his ongoing smoking and lack of exercise.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of central chest pain radiating to his left arm  which started approximately two hours ago while he was doing household chores. The pain is described as 8/10 on the pain scale and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  perspiration  and a sudden onset of nausea.   Mr. Smith's past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily  but quit five years ago. He struggles with maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise due to socioeconomic constraints and resides in an urban setting. We also note a family history of early onset coronary heart disease; his father suffered his first myocardial infarction at the age of 52.   He doesn’t take his hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications regularly due to their costs. He's currently prescribed Metformin for his diabetes  a calcium channel blocker for hypertension  and a statin for hyperlipidemia. Currently  he denies any allergies to medications.   On physiologic examination  Mr. Smith’s blood pressure on presentation is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate is 115 beats/min  respirations are 20 breaths/min  and temperature is 37.2°C.  His BMI was last measured in a clinic visit six months ago at 32 kg/m2  putting him in the obese category.  Based on the provided history and physical examination  an acute coronary syndrome  specifically acute myocardial infarction  is highly suspected.

A 68-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with acute  severe  substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and nausea. Pain started approximately two hours ago while he was doing yard work and has been continuous since then. The patient describes the pain as ""crushing  like an elephant standing on my chest."" He rates the pain as an 8 out of 10 on a numerical pain scale. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia are controlled with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively  and his diabetes is managed with metformin. He self-reports noncompliance with medications for the past three weeks. His family history reveals his father had a heart attack at age 72. He does not drink alcohol and denies illicit drug use.   Prior to today's presentation  the patient describes exertional chest pain over the past two months  which he neglected assuming it to be due to aging and overexertion. He also reveals experiencing shortness of breath with exertion and awakening from sleep due to breathlessness over the past month.   During examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. His pulse rate is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 160/100mm Hg  respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min  and SpO2 is 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals a regular rhythm without murmur  rub  or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The remainder of his physical exam is within normal limits.          Given the history and examination findings  an acute myocardial infarction is suspected. His risk factors include being male  African-American ethnicity  age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  smoking  family history of heart disease  and potential medication noncompliance.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with severe  crushing  substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain which began about 2 hours ago is associated with profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and nausea. He rates it a 10 on a scale of 10. He has no known allergies. His only medication is 81mg aspirin which he takes daily.  Relevant Past Medical History includes uncontrolled hypertension for which he was recommended to start on medications 8 months ago but refused  20-pack year history of smoking (quit 2 years ago)  and his father had a fatal heart attack at the age of 68. He has a high cholesterol level and admitted that he has a sedentary lifestyle and unhealthy diet. His BMI is 29 indicating obesity. His last routine health check was approximately 1 year ago.  His vitals on examination are: Heart rate-110 bpm  Respiratory rate - 22 breaths per minute  Blood pressure - 155/95 mmHg  Temperature- 37 °C  oxygen saturation- 91% on room air.  On cardiovascular examination  the chest is symmetrical with normal heart sounds  but there is the presence of a third heart sound (S3). There are no signs of pulmonary congestion on lung auscultation. The rest of the physical examination is not remarkable.  The suspect based on the history and examination is that Mr. Doe is currently experiencing an acute myocardial infarction  necessitating immediate further evaluation including a 12 lead ECG and cardiac enzyme testing  as well as aggressive medical management in line with AHA/ACC guidelines.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the Emergency Department with severe  crushing  central chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  which began approximately 2 hours ago. The pain is associated with dyspnea  diaphoresis  nausea and vomiting. He also mentions feeling lightheaded.   Patient History:  James is a retired construction worker  has a 30-pack year history of smoking  was diagnosied with hypertension and high cholesterol 10 years ago  and has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and statin treatment. His father had a heart attack at the age of 60. He also has a sedentary lifestyle and is obese with a body mass index of 30 kg/m2.   Medication:  James has been prescribed amlodipine 5mg and atorvastatin 40mg once daily  but admits he does not take his medication regularly.  Social History:  He lives with his wife in a suburban area. He has two adult children who live out of state. He continues to smoke 1 pack/day and consumes alcohol moderately.   Review of Systems:  On examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic. He was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm and blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg. Upon auscultation  no abnormalities were noted with his heart sounds. Cardiac enzymatic markers were ordered  and the ECG showed ST-segment elevations in leads V2-V5  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Please note that this presentation may not be typical for all patients with an acute myocardial infarction. Women  older adults  and patients with diabetes may have more atypical symptoms such as shortness of breath  back pain  or fatigue.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Franklin  presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe retrosternal chest pain. The pain began around 2 hours ago  radiates to the left arm  is accompanied by shortness of breath  and is described as a pressure or tightness likened to a ""heavy weight on the chest."" Over the past few months  he has noticed episodes of similar  but less severe chest discomfort  typically upon exertion and subsiding with rest.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed eight years ago  hyperlipidemia diagnosed 12 years ago  and smoking 20 cigarettes a day for 40 years. He is currently on hypertensive medications (lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide)  a statin (rosuvastatin) for hyperlipidemia  and metformin for diabetes. The patient admits to being inconsistent with his medication and diet control.  He has no known allergies  and his family history is significant for early heart disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction in his 50s.  In line with his symptoms and medical history  the patient is at high risk for acute myocardial infarction.  (Note: While this case reflects a standard presentation of acute myocardial infarction  it's important to remember that women  elderly patients  and those with diabetes are less likely to present with classic symptoms. Instead  they may experience symptoms such as malaise  nausea  abdominal pain  or breathlessness.)

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started about 2 hours ago. The patient describes the pain as ""something heavy sitting on my chest."" He also reports feeling short of breath  nauseous  dizzy  and sweating profusely with a fluid loss leading to weakness.   Patient's Demographics:   The patient lives in a suburban setting with his wife of 40 years. He is a retired factory worker and the primary breadwinner for his family. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and drinks alcohol socially. He admits to a diet high in saturated fats and a sedentary lifestyle due to severe osteoarthritis  which limits his mobility.   Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia previously  for which he takes atenolol and simvastatin irregularly. He is also on an NSAID  ibuprofen  for pain management of his osteoarthritis  he discloses not taking any other medication and he has no known allergies.   There is a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father had a heart attack in his early 70s  and his older brother had a stroke at 67. The patient denies any illicit drug use and does not have a history of diabetes or other heart disease. His last medical checkup was 1 year ago  at which time his blood pressure and cholesterol levels were elevated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Fields is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that began about two hours prior to his arrival. He describes the pain as crushing in nature  located centrally in his chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. According to Mr. Fields  the pain is accompanied by difficulty in breathing  diaphoresis  lightheadedness  and nausea.   He rates the pain as 8/10 on the severity scale  and states it started while he was having dinner without any significant physical exertion. He attempted to relieve the pain with rest and nitroglycerin he has at home without any relief  which is unusual for his typical angina.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and stable angina  and he has been reasonably compliant with his medications  which include Metoprolol  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years with numerous unsuccessful attempts to quit. He also admits to occasional alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use.  His father passed away at age 67 from what he believes was a ""heart attack "" and his 71-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease  suggesting a family history of cardiovascular disease.   Given the severity and duration of his symptoms  as well as his personal and family medical history  acute myocardial infarction is suspected. Complete work-up  including electrocardiogram and cardiac biomarkers  have been ordered.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male who was brought to the emergency department with complaints of intense  persistent chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and arm for the last two hours. He appears uncomfortable and is sweating profusely. He describes the pain as 'crushing' and 'very heavy ' rating it as an 8 on a scale of 10.   History of Present Illness:   The pain started while he was carrying a heavy load upstairs at his home and did not improve despite him taking rest. It is associated with shortness of breath  cold sweats  nausea and slight lightheadedness. He further denies any recent history of cough  fever  syncope  palpitating sensations  or lower limb swelling. There is no particular alleviating or aggravating factor for the pain.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a known history of hypertension for the last 10 years  type 2 diabetes for 5 years  and was a smoker for 35 years  but quit five years ago. He has a familial history of ischemic heart disease  with his father having died from a heart attack at 70. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and aspirin which he has been taking regularly. He has not undergone any previous surgical interventions.  Social and Family History:  He is retired  lives with his wife  has two adult sons  and denies any alcohol or recreational drug use. He has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father suffering a fatal heart attack in his seventies.   Review of Symptoms:  On reviewing the symptoms  he does not indicate experiencing any fever  cough  weight loss  or joint pains.   Presenting conditions suggest a potential acute myocardial infarction that warrants immediate evaluation and intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Thompson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a semi-retired mechanic  presented at the emergency department reporting severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain began approximately 2 hours ago while he was carrying some heavy boxes at home. He categorizes the pain as a crushing type  rated 8 out of 10 in severity and states it has remained constant since onset. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  sweating  and a feeling of general weakness. He denies nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness.  His health history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year history of smoking about a pack a day  although he quit about 5 years ago. He is on antihypertensive medication (lisinopril) and statins for cholesterol management. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes him to break out in hives.  His family history is notable for his father dying from myocardial infarction at age 70 and his older brother being diagnosed with angina.  Mr. Thompson's vital signs on initial presentation were: blood pressure 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 110/min  respiratory rate 22/min  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air.  Due to his symptoms  and following an abnormal EKG showing ST-elevation  he was thought to be experiencing an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 62-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe chest pain that has lasted for the past two hours. He rates the pain 8/10  describes it as ""like an elephant sitting on my chest "" and notes it radiates towards his left shoulder and arm. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath  dizziness  and nausea.   He holds an office job and has a long-established history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which have been poorly controlled due to medication noncompliance and unregulated diet. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years  has a high-fat diet and does not engage much in physical activities  although he denies drug or alcohol abuse. His father died of a heart attack at 65 years old.  His medication regimen consists of Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes and Lisinopril 20 mg once daily for hypertension  however  he sporadically takes these medications. He has no known drug allergies.   On examination  he looks anxious and is profusely sweating. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse 110/min  and respiratory rate 22/min. His oxygen saturation level is 94% while on room air. His body mass index (BMI) is 30.7  indicating obesity. Cardiac auscultations reveal tachycardia. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  No previous psychiatric issues were noted and his immunizations were up-to-date. Family history apart from his father's premature coronary artery disease is noncontributory.   The patient's history and presentation suggest a likely diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction  necessitating immediate medical intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Michael Turner  a 65-year-old African American male  comes in presenting with severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest. He describes it as ""pressure"" and states it began roughly 45 minutes before his current presentation to the ER. The pain is radiating to his left shoulder and down his left arm. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. He has never experienced an episode like this before.  Mr. Turner has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which he has managed reasonably well for the past 15 years  controlled with Metformin. He also has a diagnosis of hypertension for the last 10 years  managed with Losartan and Amlodipine. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking and admits to having a sedentary lifestyle with a high fat  high salt diet.   He has no history of surgeries in the past and he denies any allergies. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother had diabetes and hypertension. On daily medications  he takes Metformin 500mg twice a day  Losartan 50mg and Amlodipine 5mg daily. He has not taken any aspirin before presenting to the hospital.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-II diabetes mellitus  presenting with sudden onset severe substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm that started an hour ago while he was gardening. The pain is pressure-like  rating 8/10  and is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and lightheadedness.   He is a retired construction worker and has been smoking 1 pack/day for the past 40 years. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70. Mr. Johnson has been compliant with his medications which include atorvastatin  metformin  and lisinopril. However  despite the medication adherence  he shares that he has not been consistent with his diet and exercise routines.  His vital signs are as follows: BP 150/95 mmHg  HR 105 bpm  respirations 20/min  temp 98.6 F  and oxygen sat 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals an anxious appearing male in distress. His cardiovascular exam is notable for tachycardia with no murmur  and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.   Given his presentation  history  and risk factors  there is concern for an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old African American man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain that rates 8/10 in intensity. The pain started approximately three hours ago  while he was mowing the lawn  and is described as a pressing  uncomfortable sensation behind the sternum that radiated to his left arm. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom.  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  a statin for hyperlipidemia  and Lisinopril for hypertension. His father died of a heart attack in his sixties  and his older brother had a coronary artery bypass grafting at age 57.  The patient used to smoke 2 packs per day for 25 years and quit ten years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies recreational drug use. He admits adherence to his medication regimen can be challenging due to financial constraints and sometimes forgets to take his medication.  He lives at home with his wife who brought him to the hospital  fearing he was suffering from a heart attack due to the severity of the pain. The patient works as an accountant and reports high levels of stress at his job. His last general health check-up was 18 months ago. He is scared and worried about his current state of health. He is slightly overweight and is not physically active.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of sudden onset  severe  crushing chest pain which radiates to his left arm. The pain started approximately 2 hours ago while he was doing yard work and has persisted since then. He also mentions associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath.   Past medical history reveals that Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  and has been managing it with daily oral anti-diabetic medications. He also reports a diagnosis of hypertension for which he's been prescribed antihypertensive medications. He has been a smoker for approximately 30 years with a 15 cigarettes/day habit. Mr. Rodriguez mentions a family history of cardiovascular disease and stroke  specifically noting his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Physical examination shows a distressed  pale  and diaphoretic male in acute distress. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 105 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. On auscultation  the heart sounds are normal but the rhythm is irregular. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  The above-mentioned presentation is suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack)  and Mr. Rodriguez's demographic information  including age  race  and sex—along with his significant medical history (hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and family history)—fit the widely accepted risk factors as found in literature. Subsequent immediate testing and care would be needed for final diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain described as heavy crushing pain behind the sternum. Pain radiates to left arm and jaw  begun at rest and has persisted for the past 2 hours. He rates his pain as a 9 out of 10. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. The patient denies any recent trauma  fever  or cough.  Patient's vital signs are: Blood pressure: 150/90 mmHg  Pulse: 110/min  Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C)  and Respiratory rate: 22/min. Physical examination reveals cold  clammy skin and a patient in severe distress. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with normal heart sounds and no murmurs. Lung examination is clear.   The patient has a history of systemic hypertension  type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker having quit 10 years ago but has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He does not consume alcohol. He is compliant with his home medications including daily metformin  atorvastatin and amlodipine.  The patient resides with his wife in the local suburb  he is a retired mechanic with no known drug allergies. Family history includes his father who suffered a stroke at age 70 and a younger brother who had a myocardial infarction at 58. The patient has a low socio-economic status and expresses concerns about the potential costs of medical therapy.

Patient Presentation:   A 60-year-old African-American male patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain which started 2 hours before arrival. The pain is severe  characterised as pressure-like  situated in the retrosternal area and radiating to the left arm and jaw. The patient rates his pain as 9/10 on the pain scale. Accompanying symptoms include dyspnea  profuse sweating  and feelings of nausea and weakness. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is currently on medications including metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He smokes a pack of cigarettes a day  an addiction spanning roughly 40 years  and his diet is largely composed of high fat and high cholesterol foods. He works in a high-stress job and leads a largely sedentary lifestyle. There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease with his father having had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 52. His vitals at presentation are blood pressure 165/100 mm Hg  heart rate 110 bpm; respiratory rate 18 breaths pm  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. His ECG findings reveal ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads.

Patient Presentation  Patient is a 64-year-old African American male who presents with complaints of sudden-onset severe chest pain described as “crushing” that radiates to his left shoulder and down the left arm. The pain began about 2 hours ago while he was doing yard work  and it has persisted  despite rest and nitroglycerin use.  He has additional symptoms of cold sweats  nausea  feeling light headed  and shortness of breath. The patient also reports feeling anxious  adding to his discomfort. He denies any recent injuries  infections  changes in medications  or other symptoms.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed with medications for the past 15 years. He has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit about 5 years ago. He also reports a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father having died from a heart attack at the age of 70.  Physical examination shows that the patient appears diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.  Given the history and specific symptoms  a workup for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) was initiated. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads V1 to V4  consistent with an anterior wall MI. Blood work also revealed increased Troponin levels.   Subsequently  the patient was diagnosed with an ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) and was taken for emergency coronary angiography.

A 68-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a two-hour history of severe  crushing chest pain  radiating to the left arm and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He describes the discomfort as ""the worst he has ever experienced.""  He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years prior  hypertension under medical control for the last ten years  and high cholesterol that he has been managing with statins for the last eight years. He reports that both his father and elder brother had early onset heart attacks.  He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past thirty years and reports occasional alcohol use. He is active and retired from a career as a long-distance truck driver. He lives alone and is regularly checked on by an adult daughter who reports he has been increasingly forgetful recently.  Vitals on presentation include a blood pressure of 170/95 mm Hg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiration rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.  The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows significant ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads consistent with an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  The patient's chest pain  ECG changes  and risk factors including age  race  diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history  and smoking habit  altogether  suggest an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired financial advisor. He presents to the emergency department with severe crushing chest pain radiating down to his left arm and up to his jaw  associated with intense sweating and nausea which has lasted for about 45 minutes. He describes the pain as ""the worst pain I've ever felt"". The pain began while he was having dinner with his family.  He is a smoker with a 50-pack-year history and admits to consuming alcohol moderately regularly. He has a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  and type II diabetes mellitus for which he is on medication. His father had a coronary artery disease and underwent a bypass surgery at the age of 55.  Mr. Smith denies any recent changes in activity levels or diet and does not recall any major stresses or significant life events in the past few months. He denies experiencing any recent episodes of chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting prior to today.  He also reports some shortness of breath and palpitations  but denies vomiting  fever  cough  wheezing  or recent travel. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes him to have rashes. He completed a cardiac stress test 3 years ago with no significant findings.   His body mass index (BMI) is 30.5  placing him in the obesity category. His blood pressure on admission is 175/95.   The patient's symptoms and medical history are suggestive of acute myocardial infarction and warrant immediate medical attention. His relevant risk factors for cardiovascular disease including advanced age  gender  smoking  hypertension  diabetes  family history of heart disease  obesity  and high-stress occupation should be taken into consideration.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 67-year-old African-American male presenting to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain radiating to his left arm  shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweats of 2 hours' duration. He reports that the pain began suddenly while he was cleaning his garage and is not relieved by rest. The pain is described as a crushing sensation in the center of his chest  10/10 in severity.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant history of hypertension  which has been controlled with lisinopril for ten years. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years but quit five years ago. He reports moderate alcohol consumption  drinking beer on most weekends. His father died of a heart attack at 59 years old.  Social History:  He lives with his wife in the local area. He's been retired for five years  following a career in construction. He describes himself as a previously active person  walking his dog every day. However  he admits to leading a more sedentary lifestyle since retiring.  Observations:  On examination  he is conscious but appears anxious and pale  with a heart rate of 95 beats per minute  blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. He's afebrile. Chest auscultation reveals no rales or wheezes  and heart sounds are normal without any murmurs.  According to recent American Heart Association statistics  African-American individuals like Mr. Doe are at a higher risk for cardiovascular diseases  including acute myocardial infarction (AMI). His age  male gender  race  family history  hypertension  diabetes  and history of smoking further increase his risk for AMI. This presentation is consistent with ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)  and urgent reperfusion therapy should be considered after suitable investigations.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Flatley  a 65-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presented to the emergency department. She complained of sudden  severe chest pain that radiated down to her left arm. The pain started while she was doing her household chores about 2 hours ago  was constant  and described as a ""tight band around the chest."" She also reported associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  shortness of breath  and a sense of impending doom.   She has a ten-year smoking history  with one pack per day  but quit about a year ago. Patient's mother  who also had hyperlipidemia and hypertension  experienced a similar episode at the age of 70 and was diagnosed with a myocardial infarction. The patient has not undergone any surgeries previously. She has been compliant with her medications which include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.   On physical examination  she appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs demonstrated a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 bpm  a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia without any murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Other examination findings were unremarkable.   Given the patient's history  presentation  and risk factors  an acute myocardial infarction is the primary concern.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department experiencing severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and mandible  associated with profuse perspiration and shortness of breath. The pain began abruptly while he was walking his dog  approximately 45 minutes prior to presentation. He describes the pain as ‘crushing’ and unlike anything he has ever felt before. His wife  who accompanied him  reports that he looked pale and felt cold to touch during the episode.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  which have been managed with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively for the past 6 years. He has been a long-term smoker  with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He admits to non-compliance with his medications and has a sedentary lifestyle. There is no known history of drug allergies. He denies any previous similar episodes and has no history of previous hospital admissions for cardiac issues. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 70.  Social History:  He is retired and lives with his wife. He has two adult children. He consumes alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug use.   This case demonstrates a typical presentation of an acute myocardial infarction (AMI) in a demographic group (African-American male  aged >65 years) that is known to be at higher risk due to a combination of genetic and lifestyle factors. The patient's longstanding history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are risk factors for AMI  combined with his smoking history and sedentary lifestyle  increases this risk further. The onset of acute  severe and atypical chest pain brings AMI high on the differential diagnosis. The familial history of cardiac disease also contributes to his risk.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Ricardo Gutierrez is a 61-year-old Latino man who presents to the emergency department with complaints of gripping chest pain since the past 3 hours  radiating to his left arm. He rates the pain as 8 out of 10 in intensity. The pain has been constant and is associated with a sense of impending doom  profuse sweating  and lightheadedness. He adds he has never felt something like this before. He denies any recent trauma  infection or drug abuse  and has no history of allergies. He mentions associated nausea  but no vomiting.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Gutierrez has been hypertensive for the past 5 years  managed by daily antihypertensive medications. However  he has poor medication adherence. He is also a type 2 diabetic for over a decade  under oral hypoglycemics with fair glycemic control. He has a past history of smoking 10 cigarettes daily for 30 years  though he has quit for the past 5 years. Moreover  he has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father experiencing a fatal heart attack at the age of 57. He has no known chronic lung or kidney disease and no history of previous hospitalizations for heart disease. He works as a taxi driver and reports living a sedentary lifestyle.  Social History:   Mr. Gutierrez lives with his wife in a suburban population. He has two adult children who live out of state. He denies current smoking  illicit drug use or excessive alcohol intake. His diet is moderately high in fats and carbohydrates as he relies mostly on fast foods because of his work schedule. He does not take any regular exercise.   This presentation reflects data from medical literature indicating that the average age of patients having their first heart attack is around 66 for men and 70 for women  with men having a greater risk of heart attack earlier in life (AHA  2017). The patient's Latinx heritage is notable because Latinx individuals are disproportionately affected by conditions like hypertension and diabetes  which are known risk factors for heart disease. His history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and unhealthy diet are also consistent with major risk factors for MI (Yusuf et al.  2004). Full history  examination  vital signs  and investigations at the emergency department including EKG and cardiac enzymes are further needed to confirm the diagnosis and severity of the suspected acute myocardial infarction and to guide treatment.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old African American male presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of chest pain that started roughly an hour and a half ago. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that is radiating into his jaw and left arm. He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis.   Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He is a current smoker with 30-pack year smoking history. Family history reveals his father had his first heart attack at age 55.   Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. He has no known drug allergies.   This patient's demographic details and health history align with identified risk factors for myocardial infarction: being male  African American ethnicity  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and a family history of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male  Mr. Smith  presented to the emergency department complaining of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm and ongoing for the past two hours. Mr. Smith describes the pain as squeezing and heavy  rated at an 8 on a scale from 0 to 10. He also reports associated diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. There is no positional or exertional component to his symptoms.   Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  a smoker with a 40-year pack history  and has a ten-year history of inadequately controlled hypertension. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m² putting him in the obese category. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His only regular medications are amlodipine 10mg once daily and aspirin 75mg once daily.   These aforementioned factors increase his risk for coronary artery disease: smoking  hypertension  obesity  African-American ethnicity  positive family history of premature coronary artery disease  and male sex. He does not report any allergies. His last routine check-up was about a year ago  and he has not had any surgical intervention in the past.   On examination  he looks anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 102 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs or gallops  but his heart sounds are slightly muffled. His lungs are clear to auscultation.  This presentation is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  possibly due to coronary artery disease  and warrants further investigation.

Patient Presentation:  Joseph  a 67-year-old Caucasian male patient  presents to the emergency department with central chest discomfort of about an hour's duration. The discomfort is described as a severe  crushing sensation radiating to his left arm and neck. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  and a 30-year history of smoking  approximately one pack per day.   He was amenable to dietary and lifestyle changes and took medication as prescribed  but his compliance on the smoking cessation program was poor. His blood pressure today is found to be elevated at 165/95 mmHg and his heart rate is irregular at 92 beats per minute. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. His lipid profile was known to be borderline high during his checkup six months ago  but he was not compliant with the statin therapy his doctor had suggested.  Joseph lives alone since his wife passed away two years ago and he has two daughters living out of state. His alcohol consumption has increased  as per his account  over the past year. He retired five years ago from his job as an electrical engineer  tends to lead a sedentary lifestyle and reports his level of daily stress as moderate. He denies recreational drug use.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe chest pain. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" and rates it as 10/10. The pain began about one hour ago while he was resting  and has remained constant. He also reports associated shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.  Demographics:   The patient is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife  and has two adult children. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol moderately  and denies any illicit drug use. He follows a high-fat diet  rarely exercises and is overweight. He does not have a family history of heart disease.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are poorly controlled. He has a history of taking medication irregularly and has not seen his primary care physician in over a year.  Background Information:   Considering the literature  African American men are at a higher risk of developing coronary artery disease. Also  this patient’s age  diabetes  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and diet increase his risk of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  constricting chest pain that has been intermittent for the last 12 hours. The pain is localized to the center of the chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw.  The pain is 8 out of 10 in severity  not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin  and comes with shortness of breath and profuse sweating. He characterizes the chest pain as crushing and states that it is unlike any pain he has experienced before.  Mr. Smith also reports associated symptoms of nausea and dizziness. He says  ""I feel like I’m going to pass out."" He denies experiencing any fever  cough  urinary or bowel complaints. He was well until the onset of this abrupt  severe chest pain while doing yard work.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are managed with enalapril and metformin  respectively. His family history reveals that his father died of heart attack at the age of 67.   Mr. Smith is a retired police officer. He admits to a 30-pack-year history of smoking. He quit about 5 years ago  around the time he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He consumes alcohol on social occasions but denies any illicit drug use.  He lives with his wife in their own home. They have 3 adult children who live out of state.  This brief history consistent with acute coronary syndrome  specifically a potential acute myocardial infarction  requiring immediate assessment and intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the Emergency Department with ongoing crushing central chest pain  which commenced suddenly while he was mowing his lawn. He describes the pain as severe  'like an elephant standing on my chest.'  The pain radiates to his left arm and up to his jaw. It is associated with profuse sweating  dizziness and nausea. His wife noticed he appeared pale and clammy and insisted he come to the hospital.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia  for which he is on Amlodipine 5mg and Atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively. He reports adherence to these medications. He also mentions that he used to smoke almost a pack a day for 30 years before he quit 10 years ago.  He denies any recent illnesses  chest infections or other complaints and his immunizations are up to date. His family history is significant for his father having suffered a heart attack in his sixties. Mr. Smith is retired and lives with his wife  and their diet is high in fat and salt.  On examination  Mr. Smith appears anxious and in distress. He is afebrile  and his vital signs show a blood pressure of 160/90mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min and oxygen saturations 94% on room air.  The EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads and he is immediately started on aspirin  nitrates  and a heparin drip as per acute myocardial infarction (MI) protocol. The blood test results confirm elevated troponin levels.   This patient has several risk factors for Cardiovascular disease-family history  history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  previous smoker  diet high in fat and salt  and age over 60. His presentation and investigations favors a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain that began approximately two hours prior to arrival. The pain started suddenly while he was resting at home. Mr. Johnson describes the pain as ""a heavy weight on my chest "" noting that it radiates down his left arm and up into his jaw. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea.   He rates the pain as an 8 on a scale from 0 to 10  with 10 being the worst pain possible  and says that it does not improve with rest or movement. Over the counter NSAIDs did not provide any relief.  Ibsen's past medical history includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. The patient is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago  having smoked a pack a day for thirty years prior. He consumes alcohol moderately and denies recreational drug use. He does not have a family history of early coronary artery disease.  The patient’s current medications include metformin  a statin medication  and an ACE inhibitor prescribed by his primary care physician. He is compliant with his medications and has regular follow-ups. He says he tries to maintain a balanced diet and do low-intensity exercises regularly.  His vital signs on presentation are: blood pressure 158/96 mmHg  pulse rate 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. During physical examination  the patient appears acutely distressed  anxious  and sweaty but is orientated to time  place  and person.  This case presentation is a fairly typical presentation of acute myocardial infarction in the demographic group most commonly affected. Older age  being male  African-American ethnicity  and having type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia are all significant risk factors for myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J  a 66-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department (ED) with acute severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and shoulder. The pain has been on and off for the past 6 hours and is associated with shortness of breath  and diaphoresis. The patient appears pale and anxious.  He is a retired truck driver and a veteran  living with his wife. He has a 20-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He states that he has been compliant with his medications for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus but admits to a diet high in saturated fats and with minimal physical activity.  Personal history further includes a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at age 60. Mr. J has no known drug allergies.  Mr. J has not been hospitalized before this. He denies alcohol consumption. He admits to daily self-monitoring of blood glucose  with most readings within the recommended prediabetic range. He states he was last seen by a healthcare provider 6 months ago where his blood pressure was within target range. Recent HbA1c was 7.4% - indicating poor blood sugar control in recent months.  On examination  BP is 150/90 mmHg  pulse 98/min  and respiratory rate 22/min. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia  and S4 gallop is heard on auscultation. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Body Mass Index is 32 kg/m2 - qualifying as obese. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  consistent with anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient has been rushed to the cath lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention as a part of STEMI protocol.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old African American male  Mr. B  a retired mechanic  presents to the emergency department complaining of intense  crushing chest pain for last 2 hours. He describes the pain as being heavy  with a rating of 8/10 and says the pain radiates to his left arm and jaw. He tells you that it started while he was at rest  after his dinner and did not get better after taking rest.   Mr B. also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. He has also felt lightheaded and dizzy. He denies any prior similar episode. Patient is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus in last 10 years. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 69 and mother suffered from a stroke in her late 50s.   Smoking history reveals a 20-pack-year history but has quit since 5 years. Patient admits drinking alcohol on social occasions only. He used to do regular workouts  but had left it for a few months due to lockdown restrictions. His medications include metformin and losartan. He is not allergic to any medications.  On Examination:  Vital signs: Blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg  pulse 110/min  irregular  respiratory rate 24 breaths/min  increased  temperature is normal and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  Cardiovascular examination: Heart sounds S1 and S2 are present with no murmurs  but rapid irregular beats are noted.   The patient's presentation is concerning for acute myocardial infarction. He requires immediate EKG and lab assessment  including cardiac enzymes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and episodes of syncope. The pain described is severe  approximately an 8/10  occurs at rest  unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerine  and has been present for approximately three hours.   Past Medical History:  The patient is a retired construction worker  and his health history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication (chlorthalidone and atorvastatin). Mr. Doe has a 40-pack year smoking history and reports moderate alcohol use. There is a family history of heart disease - his father had a myocardial infarction at 62 years old.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. Doe appears in distress. His blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respirations 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed diminished heart sounds  no murmur or rub. His skin was cool  pale  and sweaty.   Additional Notes:  These findings are consistent with suspected acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Immediate actions would include obtaining an EKG  initiating supplemental oxygen  administering aspirin and nitroglycerin  and calling for an urgent cardiology consultation.   Demographic representation is reflective of data that suggests that males are at increased risk of developing coronary artery disease  the majority of AMI patients have hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a significant percentage are smokers. Furthermore  Caucasians have a relatively higher risk of AMI compared to other races. The presentation also mirrors the typical symptoms of AMI including chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. Other common symptoms seen in the emergency department include shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and sweating.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male  retired government worker  living alone in an urban setting. He presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as severe heaviness in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain has been continuous  not relieved by rest  rated as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. Accompanied by diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom.   He has a past medical history significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin  hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago after 20 years of smoking  and occasionally drinks alcohol. His father died of a heart attack in his early 60s and his mother has a history of stroke.  Mr. Johnson has no known allergies. His regular medications include 500mg of Metformin twice a day  20mg of Lisinopril once daily  and 40mg of Atorvastatin once daily. He states he tries to exercise a few times a week by taking walks around his neighborhood but admits his diet could use improvement. He lives alone and is independent with all activities of daily living. He is visibly distressed upon presentation  anxious  and in pain  with a slight wheeze audible upon examination.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African American male patient comes to the emergency department presenting with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain began 2 hours ago while he was at rest  and it is described as a heavy pressure-like sensation  rated as 9/10 in severity. The patient also mentions shortness of breath and a cold  clammy feeling.  Demographics:   The patient is a retired factory worker living in a suburban neighborhood in Ohio. He has a history of 30-pack-years cigarette smoking but quit two years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally. He takes no illicit drugs. His diet is high in sodium and fat  and he exercises minimally.   Medical history:  His medical history reveals poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease three years ago. His family history also reveals cardiovascular disease. His father died from a myocardial infarction at age 64. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension but has poor medication adherence.   Background:  The incidence of myocardial infarction (MI) is higher in African American men  especially over the age of 60  who have risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  smoking  lifestyle  and family history. The pain characteristics and patient's clinical background are suggestive of an acute MI.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with a two-hour history of sudden onset  severe  central chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation  rated 8 out of 10 in intensity  and has been persistent despite taking his prescribed nitroglycerin tablets. He has been feeling short of breath and has broken out in a cold sweat. He also reports nausea and light-headedness.  John has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  for which he has been taking Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively  for the past ten years. He was a smoker for 30 years  averaging about 1 pack/day  and quit smoking just 1 year ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. Otherwise  John does not consume alcohol  denies illicit drug use  and is sedentary in his lifestyle  with a body mass index of 32.   John lives at home with his wife  is retired  and states that he has not been feeling depressed or anxious. His immunizations and colorectal cancer screening are up-to-date. His diet is high in fat and he does not engage in regular exercise. He does not monitor his blood glucose levels regularly.  Summary: Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a previous long history of smoking  presenting with classic symptoms of acute myocardial infarction.

A 67-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm  occurring at rest  and associated with shortness of breath  dizziness  and diaphoresis. It has been ongoing for about 30 minutes. The patient rates it 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.  He has known history of diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient was a 20-pack year smoker but quit 5 years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His daily medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin taken regularly.  On examination  he appears diaphoretic  anxious and in distress. Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. The chest is normal on auscultation  there are no added heart sounds  and the cardiac examination is otherwise unremarkable.   Electrocardiogram reveals ST segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Immediate management and stabilization measures are put into place as per acute myocardial infarction protocol.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 63-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain  radiating to the left arm  for the past 3 hours. The pain is associated with sweating  nausea and shortness of breath.   He is a two-pack per day smoker for the last 40 years  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has a sedentary lifestyle. His diet primarily includes high-fat and high-sodium foods.  Relevant Past Medical History:  He was diagnosed with Type-2 diabetes 5 years back and is on oral hypoglycemic drugs since then. He has a history of hypertension for the past 7 years and is on antihypertensive therapy. He does not have any known allergies. He has a family history of early myocardial infarction among male relatives with his father having suffered a heart attack at the age of 50.  According to research data  majority of heart attack patients are men and occur over the age of 45. Additionally  risk factors associated with heart disease include smoking  diabetes  hypertension  a sedentary lifestyle and a family history of heart disease. Individuals with a Hispanic background are particularly at risk due to prevalence of several of these risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who comes to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to his left arm that started an hour ago while resting at home. The pain is characterized as crushing and is accompanied by cold sweat  shortness of breath  and nausea. He grades the pain as 8 on a 10-point scale. He reports that he has never had such a pain before.   Regarding his medical history  he has been managing hypertension for the past 15 years and type 2 diabetes for 10 years  both of which are controlled on medication. He also mentions that he used to smoke 2 packs per day but quit about five years ago  though he still drinks alcohol socially.  Family history is significant for his father  who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He states that he has been compliant with his medications but admits that his diet lacks fruits and vegetables. He has been taking Metformin 1g twice a day for diabetes  and for his hypertension  he has been on Lisinopril 20mg daily.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain  predominantly on the left side of his chest  started approximately 5 hours ago  radiates to his left arm and is described as a squeezing and heavy sensation. His dyspnea has been gradually becoming more severe over the past few hours.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and has been smoking for the past 40 years. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. His father passed away at 55 due to a heart attack. The patient has been non-compliant with his medications and rarely exercises.  On physical examination  he appears diaphoretic and anxious. His blood pressure is 157/92 mmHg  heart rate is 96 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. He is afebrile. Cardiovascular examination reveals soft s1 and s2 heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His lung sounds are clear bilaterally and he is maintaining an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.  An EKG is performed and shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF. The patient is given aspirin  nitroglycerin  and a loading dose of a P2Y12 inhibitor  and the STEMI protocol is activated.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe chest pain.  Presenting Problem:   He describes the pain as ""crushing "" rated 8 out of 10  radiating to his left arm and jaw. He experienced sudden onset of symptoms while at rest at home  approximately an hour ago. He also reports profuse sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath but denies any fainting  dizziness  or palpitations. He took aspirin immediately when the symptoms begun  but the pain did not subside. He has never experienced symptoms like these before.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past six years. He has been on regular medication but occasionally misses follow-ups due to financial constraints. He also admits to a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes a day but denies alcohol or any illicit drug use. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 65.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Smith appears anxious and is profusely sweating. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg  pulse rate is 100 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. His heart rate is regular  but there are occasional extrasystoles. Chest auscultation reveals no abnormal breath sounds. His body mass index is 32.  Based on his symptoms  risk factors  and physical examination findings  an acute myocardial infarction is suspected  and Mr. Smith is immediately referred for an electrocardiogram and cardiac enzyme studies. Because of his age  race  and history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking  he is at high risk for a heart attack.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department (ED) with an acute onset of severe chest pain  radiating to his left shoulder and jaw. The patient reported that he was sitting at home when the pain suddenly began around two hours ago  and it had grown progressively worse over time. He described the pain as ‘crushing ’ rating it at 8 on a pain scale of 0-10  and added that it was associated with profuse sweating and shortness of breath. His past medical history revealed a diagnosis of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are being managed with medication. Additionally  there’s a family history of early heart disease. He admitted to being a smoker for 40 years and consuming alcohol occasionally.  He denied any similar episodes in the past  and had not taken any medication for the pain prior to coming to the ED. The patient seemed anxious and in distress  which was notable on initial impression. He had no known allergies. His medications included Metformin for diabetes and Losartan for hypertension. He was up-to-date with annual physical examinations  the last of which did not identify any severe abnormalities or cause for concern.   The significance of this case is amplified due to the patient’s demographic and lifestyle factors  including age  race  male sex  hypertensive and diabetic status  history of smoking  and family history of early heart disease  all of which increase susceptibility to myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of intense central chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain started while he was tending his garden  one hour ago  associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He describes the pain as ""heavy"" and ""crushing "" rating it a 10/10 on the pain scale.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  which has been controlled with Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively over the past 8 years. He stopped smoking 10 years ago but had a 30-pack year history prior to quitting. He uses alcohol socially and denies any use of illicit drugs.  Family History:  His father had a history of heart disease and suffered a myocardial infarction at age 65. His older sister is currently living with heart failure.
