Review of Symptoms:   The patient admits to some intermittent chest discomfort over the past month  particularly during bouts of strenuous physical activity  but it always resolved with rest. He has never experienced pain to this severity before. He denies headaches  changes in vision  and difficulty in speech or swallowing.   This presentation  in combination with his past medical and family histories  raise a high suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction. An EKG and serum cardiac markers should be done immediately to confirm the diagnosis.

A 65-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with intense  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  which started around 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as exertional  not relieved by rest  and associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweats. He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under suboptimal control with medications. He reports being an active smoker  with approximately 30-pack years. He admits to limited physical activity and a diet high in fat and cholesterol. A decade ago  his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at an age similar to the patient's current age. This patient does not have any personal history of coronary artery disease  but with his family history  lifestyle  and existing comorbid conditions  he has substantial risk factors for acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain that radiates to the left jaw and arm accompanied with sweating  shortness of breath  and nausea. He reports the pain started 3 hours prior while watching television. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation that is unusual for him. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and has been for 40 years.   Past Medical History:  His medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia  and obesity with a BMI of 33. He is compliant with metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at age 55. He is unemployed and admits he lives a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Paramedics administered 325 mg of aspirin in the ambulance  and upon arrival  an ECG showed ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. His blood pressure on presentation was 150/90 mmHg  heart rate was 94 beats/minute  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of severe left-sided chest pain  radiating to the left arm. The pain is continuous  moderate to severe in intensity (8/10)  described as a sensation of ""heavy pressure"" and began suddenly about an hour ago while he was doing yard work. It was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. He had to stop what he was doing immediately due to the intensity of the pain. The pain did not alleviate with rest.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes medication  but admits to not always taking these. He had a small stroke 3 years ago with full recovery. He has been a smoker for about 30 years and admits to a diet high in fat and cholesterol. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70. He has no history of previous heart disease himself.   Additional Details: The patient lives alone and is retired. He drinks alcohol occasionally  denies illicit drug use  and has no known drug allergies. He does not have a regular exercising routine. His body mass index is 32 indicating obesity.  This presentation and history place the patient at high risk for Acute Myocardial Infarction.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with 1-hour history of severe  crushing  central chest pain radiating down the left arm and up to the jaw. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and mild nausea. His vital signs on admission include a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 per min  temperature 98.6°F  and a pulse oximetry reading of 92% on room air.  The patient is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  and has a smoking history of 30-pack years. He admits to drinking alcohol socially  mostly on weekends. He is obese with a BMI of 32  on a regular diet  and has been sedentary for the last several years. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he is on amlodipine  and type 2 diabetes which he manages with metformin.  His diet is predominantly high in cholesterol and trans-fat and he admits to non-compliance with his medications. He denies any recent travel or surgery. His father passed away at the age of 59 due to ischemic heart disease. His family history is positive for coronary artery disease.  The physical examination reveals diaphoresis and some discomfort while talking. He appears anxious. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal heart sounds with no audible murmurs  gallops  or rubs. No jugular venous distention is observed. Pulmonary examination is consistent with mild tachypnea  but clear to auscultation bilaterally.   Given the age  sex  smoking history  family history of heart disease  obesity  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and clinical manifestation  he is suspected to have an acute myocardial infarction.  EMS had given him 162mg of aspirin enroute. Currently  ECG and cardiac enzymes are awaited  and the patient is being managed according to the acute coronary syndrome protocol. He is being kept nil per os (NPO) in anticipation of possible need for urgent cardiac catheterization.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Lopez is a 65-year-old Hispanic male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  severe central chest pain which radiated to his left arm starting about two hours ago. The pain is described as a heavy pressure sensation  rated 8 out of 10  and not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea and slight shortness of breath.   Medical history:   Mr. Lopez has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He has been non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic medications. His last recorded blood pressure at a primary care appointment 3 months ago was 150/90 mmHg. He has a family history suggesting early coronary artery disease as his father died of a heart attack at the age of 58.   Social history:   Mr. Lopez is a retiree  married with four children. He has a history of heavy smoking but denies alcohol or illicit drug usage. Since he’s retired  he has lived a sedentary lifestyle.  Review of systems:  Positive for recent episodes of fatigue and indigestion mistaken for gastric troubles over the last week. Denied headaches  fever  chills  cough  urinary or bowel complaints.   Physical examination:  Vital signs upon arrival: BP: 155/95 mmHg  Heart Rate: 96 beats per minute  Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per minute  Temperature: 98.6 F  SpO2: 94% on room air.   He appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia  normal S1 and S2  without any murmurs  rubs  gallops  or extra heart sounds. Pulmonary  abdominal and neurological exams are unremarkable. No pedal edema is observed.

Patient Presentation:  John Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe  crushing chest pain that started about three hours ago. He describes the pain as ""an elephant sitting on my chest "" with radiation to his left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  and lightheadedness. He also admits to having similar  but comparatively mild symptoms over the past one week  which he attributed to indigestion. Currently a smoker  he admits to smoking one pack daily for the past 40 years. His father had a heart attack at the age of 60. Mr. Smith has a sedentary lifestyle and confirms a diet high in saturated fats with little to no exercise.   He is currently taking Metformin for his type 2 diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension. There is no known drug allergy. He is unemployed  recently divorced  and lives alone. His alcohol consumption is within acceptable limits  but he admits to feeling stressed due to recent life events.   Physical examination reveals that Mr. Smith is alert and oriented but appears to be in acute distress. Vital signs include blood pressure 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 105 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  oxygen saturation 94% on room air and temperature 98.6°F. Examination of the cardiovascular system reveals tachycardia with no audible murmurs  rubs  or gallops  and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Based upon his medical history  symptoms  and ECG findings  an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (heart attack) is highly suspected.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents in the emergency room with acute  severe  substernal chest pain that started about one hour ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is described as crushing in nature  radiating to his left shoulder and down to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include feeling short of breath  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom. His sister  who is with him  noticed that he has become very pale and seems a little confused.  Past Medical History:  On delving into his past medical history  we find that Mr. Smith is a retired truck driver whose diet mainly consists of fast foods high in fats  due to his previous occupation. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension diagnosed eight years ago and type 2 diabetes diagnosed three years ago. He is presently being managed on oral anti-diabetic medication and anti-hypertensives  but admits he is not always compliant with medication usage or blood pressure and blood sugar monitoring. He also admits to having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years  but quit smoking one year ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died at the age of 65 from a heart attack.  The patient is obese  and regular physical activity is not part of his lifestyle. He denies any known allergies but admits to excessive alcohol consumption during his young adult years  although he has since moderated his drinking habits. His mother died at the age of 75 after suffering from a stroke. He is divorced and lives alone  and his two adult children live out of state. He reports feeling isolated and admits to some episodes of depression over the last year since he retired  though he has not sought treatment.   Given this information  it seems that Mr. Smith is at high risk for cardiovascular diseases like acute myocardial infarction  due to his advancing age  male gender  uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  a history of smoking  poor diet  lack of physical activity  high stress  isolation  depression and strong family history of cardiovascular diseases.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient named John presents to the emergency department (ED) with symptoms of severe  crushing  and substernal chest pain that has been radiating to his left arm and jaw for the past few hours. He rates the intensity of his pain as an 8 out of 10. John also reports episodes of cold sweats  difficulty in breathing  and a feeling of imminent doom. He states that his symptoms started while he was doing some heavy lifting in his backyard.   John has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which were diagnosed around 5 years ago. He is currently taking a combination of metformin and sitagliptin for his diabetes and amlodipine for his hypertension.   John has been a heavy smoker for the past 40 years  consuming a pack a day. His drinking habits include occasional beer during weekends. He admits that he lives a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity due to his job as a truck driver. His father had a heart attack at the age of 60.   John is currently living with his wife and their dog. He reported that he had his last meal around 4-5 hours ago  and there was no recent change in his diet which is typically high in salt and fats. He denies any recent travel  significant levels of stress  or any over-the-counter medication or substance use other than his regular prescribed medications.   This is his first visit to the ED with such severe chest discomfort. He shared that he has been ignoring intermittent chest discomfort over the past few weeks thinking it was due to gastric issues. However  today's pain made him very concerned  prompting him to seek immediate medical help.   In this clinical scenario  the implicative signs for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) are his age  gender  and specific symptoms  as well as the significant risk factors such as history of hypertension  diabetes  heavy smoking  physical inactivity  family history of heart disease  and possible unnoticed angina.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Patrick Thomson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of progressively worsening chest pain over the last 2 hours. He describes the pain as a heaviness in the center of his chest  radiating to his left shoulder and down the inside of his left arm. He also indicates dyspnea  diaphoresis  and feelings of weakness or fatigue. He denies recent illnesses  denies cough or fever  and currently has no nausea or vomiting.  Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He has been on Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin for the past 5 years to manage these conditions. He is a previous smoker of 10 years  but quit smoking five years ago. His father underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at age 60 and his mother had a stroke at age 80.  Social History:  Occupationally  the patient is a retired engineer. He is married with three adult children. He admits to a history of moderate alcohol use but stopped drinking after diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes. He denies any illicit drug use.  Conclusion:  Based on his presentation and past history  he is highly suspected for acute myocardial infarction. Immediate medical attention including EKG and cardiac enzymes test is necessary to manage his clinical condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the ER with complaints of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain started suddenly while he was doing yard work two hours ago  and it has been persistent since then. He describes it as a ""heavy weight"" on his chest. Accompanying symptoms include difficulty in breathing  light-headedness  heavy sweating  and a general feeling of impending doom.  He has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and high cholesterol. He has been taking metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin regularly. He does not have any known drug allergies. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol moderately. His father passed away due to a 'heart attack' at the age of 70.  On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Vitals include blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  An EKG has been ordered immediately  and the patient is currently receiving sublingual nitroglycerin for symptom relief.    This brief presentation mirrors prevalent demographic trends in myocardial infarction  with African American men having higher rates of hypertension and diabetes  both risk factors for heart disease. Also  smoking  a significant contributor to the development of coronary artery disease  is incorporated in this patient's history  mirroring real-world patterns. This showcases a typical presentation of an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. T Johnson  a 62-year-old African American Male  presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain. He describes the pain as a crushing  heaviness in the middle of his chest that started about 2 hours ago while he was gardening at home. The pain appeared suddenly  radiating to his left arm and neck. He also reports feeling short of breath  sweating profusely  and experiencing some nausea. No history of trauma or injury was reported.  Past Medical History:  Interestingly  he has a relevant medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  each diagnosed 7 years ago  though he has been non-compliant with medications with irregular follow-ups. He also reports a 20-pack-year smoking history  having started in his early 20s  and leading a sedentary lifestyle. He has a family history of early cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction when he was 58 years old.   Remarks:  These factors  demographic (being an older  African-American male)  and the presence of multiple risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  smoking  family history) make Mr. Johnson particularly susceptible to coronary artery disease  which may have resulted in an acute myocardial infarction in this case. Immediate management and further diagnostic tests need to be done to confirm the diagnosis and start appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 58-year-old African American male from East Harlem. He presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck. The pain started at rest approximately 3 hours prior to arrival  described as a heavy pressure and grading it as 8/10 in severity. Accompanying symptoms include diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and nausea. He denies having fever  cough  chest trauma  or difficulty breathing but reports similar  though less severe  episodes of chest pain in the past month.   Mr. Doe is a former smoker who has been tobacco-free for 15 years but does admit to drinking alcohol moderately on weekends. He has no known drug allergies. He has a past medical history of diabetes type 2  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin respectively. The patient does not engage in regular exercise and mainly follows a diet high in saturated fats. Family history includes a father who died of heart disease at 62 and a mother with cerebrovascular disease.   The patient has no current or past psychiatric diagnosis or treatment. His immunizations are up-to-date. His profession is listed as a bus driver. The patient is married and lives with his wife and two adult children. History shows no previous issue of domestic violence or abuse.  The vital signs on admission are temperature 98.6°F  heart rate 115 per minute  blood pressure 160/95 mmHg  respirations 24 per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on ambient air. Preliminary cardiac examination reveals Tachycardia; however  other systems' examination is unremarkable. The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior-lateral leads. The patient's presentation and ECG findings are consistent with an acute anterior-lateral myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Walker is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain described as ""pressure"" radiating down his left arm  associated with diaphoresis  nausea and shortness of breath for the last three hours.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Walker has a history of controlled hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril 20mg daily  hyperlipidemia managed with Simvastatin 40 mg daily  and a 40-pack year smoking history  but quit smoking ten years ago. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago with complete recovery and is on low dose Aspirin 81mg daily. He denies any previous history of coronary artery disease or congestive heart failure. His father passed away at 65 from a heart attack.   Physical Examination:  He is a well built  slightly obese person appearing his stated age and in moderate distress. Vital signs show blood pressure 165/95 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per minute  body temperature 37.1°C and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. The cardio-respiratory examination reveals tachypnea  and heart sounds show no murmurs or gallops. His EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads  indicative of an acute myocardial infarction.  Considering his presentation and clinical background  he matched with the demographic most often associated with myocardial infarction; male  over 60 years of age  with high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and a significant smoking history. Immediate management of his condition  including reperfusion therapy  is initiated  and cardiology is consulted.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male comes to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  crushing pain in the center of his chest which started roughly one hour ago at rest. He rates the pain as a 10 out of 10  describing it as a squeezing sensation  accompanied by excessive sweating  nausea  and intermittent dizziness which is not relieved by rest or movement. He denies experiencing any trauma or injury to the chest.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) and a 30-pack year history of smoking cigarettes. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 approximately five years ago. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 58. He does not have a regular exercise regimen or follow any specific diet plan.   Medication:  The patient takes once daily Metformin 500 mg for his diabetes and Lisinopril 10 mg for hypertension. He has no known drug allergies.  Social History:  The patient is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife  and has two adult children. He smoked a half pack of cigarettes a day for 60 years  but quit a year ago. However  he admits to not exercising regularly or maintaining a healthy diet. His alcohol use is occasional during social events.   Family History:  His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. His father had a myocardial infarction at 58 years of age  and his mother has long-standing hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with high cholesterol.    Review of Systems:  He admits to having experienced mild chest pain occasionally over the past six months  which he attributed to indigestion and did not seek medical attention for. He has been feeling increasingly fatigued over these past few months but has not experienced any fever  weight loss  cough  dyspnea  leg swelling  palpitations  or syncope.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he is alert and oriented but appears visibly distressed due to pain. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse is 100/min and regular  respiratory rate is 18/min  and his body temperature is 98°F (36.7°C). His body mass index (BMI) is 28  indicative of being overweight.   This patient's clinical presentation  along with his significant cardiovascular risk factors including age  race  hypertension  DM  family history of CAD and long-term smoking habits  suggests he may be experiencing an acute myocardial infarction and immediate assessment and intervention is required to confirm diagnosis and provide appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm that started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as ""crushing"" in nature  associated with shortness of breath  sweating  and a sense of impending doom. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit five years ago.  The patient's hypertension and diabetes have been reasonably controlled with medications  which include metformin 1000mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20mg daily  and atorvastatin 40mg daily. His last HbA1C taken 3 months back was 7.3. He has no known drug allergies.  Mr. Thompson is retired  lives with his wife  and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He denies any recreational drug use. He consumes alcohol socially  reporting one to two standard drinks per week. He attends regular GP visits but admits that he has been less compliant over the past six months due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  On examination  Mr. Thompson appears in obvious distress. Initial vitals reveal a blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  temperature 36.8 degrees Celsius  and oxygen saturations 94% on room air. The cardiovascular system exam reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Immediate ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggesting an anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  smoking  and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with acute onset  severe  central chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain is a crushing sensation  rates as an 8/10 on a pain scale  and has been ongoing for the past one hour. The symptoms began while he was exerting himself in his backyard garden but has not improved with rest. He also reports shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and light-headedness. He took a single aspirin at home prior to arrival with no improvement in symptoms. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. There is no known drug allergy.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm that started about two hours ago. The pain is described as a heavy  crushing sensation  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating.  Demographics:   The patient is a resident of an urban area  retired  with a high school level education  previously employed as a factory worker. He is a widower with two adult children. He is an ex-smoker and admits to drinking alcohol moderately.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus both controlled with medication. He reports that his father died of a heart attack in his early sixties. He had an episode of chest pain five years ago  which was deemed to be angina and has been on aspirin and a statin since then.  Physical Exam:  On examination  the patient appears in distress due to pain. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths per min  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung fields are clear. Extremities show no edema. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Lab Tests/Preliminary Diagnosis:  Based on the severity of pain  history  risk factors  and physical examination  preliminary diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is made pending lab results and ECG findings.  This example scenario accurately matches demographic representation data found in literature  where African American males  especially those with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and familial history of coronary artery disease  are at a higher risk of acute myocardial infarction. The patient’s age  ethnicity  socio-economic background  and previous history of angina further underscore the high likelihood of this pathological event.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis is a 62-year-old African American male presenting to the Emergency Department (ED) with chief complaints of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw that started two hours ago. The pain is 8/10 in intensity  persistent  and not alleviated by rest.  Past Medical History -   Mr. Davis has known Hypertension (HTN) which has been fairly controlled with medication. However  he has a significant smoking history  with 30 pack-years  and a diet high in saturated fats. His paternal history is significant for fatal myocardial infarction (MI) at the age of 55. Mr. Davis is non-compliant with his prescribed anti-hypertensive medications  and has had inconsistent follow-ups with his primary care provider.   Additional Information –   On initial observation  Mr. Davis looks acutely distressed and diaphoretic. His heart rate is 110 beats/min  blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg  respiratory rate is 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads indicative of an inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).   Given the presentation  medical history  and ECG findings  the ED physician initiated the hospital's acute MI protocol to rapidly mobilize the cardiac catheterization team and informed the patient of the need for immediate reperfusion therapy.  Note: By using an African American male  we acknowledge that MI presents more often in men than in women (with a 3:1 ratio until age 70)  and African Americans have a higher risk of MI due to a higher incidence of risk factors such as hypertension. His age falls within the most common age range (55-64) for first MI. Additionally  HTN  smoking  dietary factor  family history  and non-compliance to treatment are also commonly noted risk factors for MI.

Patient Presentation:  A 66-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a one-hour history of severe  central chest pain. The pain is described as heavy and crushing  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include profound sweating and difficulty in breathing. He reports feeling lightheaded and fearing that he might pass out.  His medical history is significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed seven years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed three years ago. He is also a past smoker; he quit smoking around four years back after a smoking history of two packs per day for twenty years. He admits to non-compliance with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. There is a documented family history of premature coronary artery disease; his father suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.   Patient is on lisinopril 20mg once daily for hypertension  and metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes type II. Physical examination reveals an overweight male (BMI 28.2) in acute distress  with elevated blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg  pulse of 110 bpm  respirations 24 /min  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Initial EKG changes are consistent with acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Societal factors: Patient reports working as a bus driver  living alone with little social support  and facing financial stressors that often prevent him from affording his medications regularly. He also admits to having a diet high in saturated fats and carbohydrates  which combined with his sedentary lifestyle  has led to his weight gain.   This case is representative as African American men are one of the highest risk groups for acute myocardial infarction  with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and smoking contributing to this. The patient’s age also corresponds to the median age of onset of myocardial infarction in men  which is approximately 65.6 years.

A 64-year-old Caucasian male comes to the ER complaining of intense  crushing chest pain that started 2 hours ago. The pain is radiating down the left arm and also accompanied by sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. Blood pressure upon admission is 150/90 mmHg  and heart rate is 110 beats per minute. He is a retired truck driver  with a history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Family history revealed his father had a heart attack at the age of 59 years. He is not currently on any prescription medications and denies any possible drug allergies. He mentions he uses OTC NSAIDS occasionally for chronic knee pain. An ECG is quickly performed  which shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Ahmed  a 58-year-old South Asian male  presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset  severe  left-sided chest pain radiating down his left arm. The pain is crushing in nature and started about 45 minutes ago while he was at work. He reports feeling sweaty  nauseous  and increasingly short of breath. He rates his pain as 8 out of 10. He denies falling or any trauma. He also mentions experiencing episodes of similar  but less intense  chest pain during strenuous activity over the past month  which resolved with rest.   Mr. Ahmed has a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both diagnosed around 10 years ago. He takes Metformin and Losartan daily. He quit smoking five years ago after a 20-year pack-a-day smoking history  but admits drinking alcohol socially. He does not exercise regularly and works as a taxi driver. He admits his diet is poor and high in fats and carbohydrates. He has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father dying of a heart attack at age 60. He has never had surgery and is not allergic to any known medications.  Height: 170 cm; Weight: 85 kg; BMI: 29.4; BP: 164/98 mmHg; Heart Rate: 102 bpm; Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per min; Oxygen Saturation: 95% on room air; Temperature: 98.6 F (37 C). On examination  he appears anxious  sweaty  and in distress due to the pain.  This presentation suggests that Mr. Ahmed has an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). His risk factors include his age  male gender  South Asian ethnicity  prior type II diabetes  hypertension  history of smoking  family history of coronary artery disease  poor diet  lack of physical exercise  chronic stress from work as a taxi driver  and episodes of chest pain during exertion.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with roughly three hours of continuous  severe chest pain. The pain started while he was at home watching television. He describes the pain as a ""crushing sensation"" in the center of his chest  radiating down his left arm and up to his jaw. He rates his pain a 10 on a 10-point scale. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a 30-pack-a-year smoker and admits to a sedentary lifestyle  poor diet  and minimal alcohol use.  He takes Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 1000mg twice a day for diabetes  and Lipitor 40mg at night for hyperlipidemia. He does not report any allergies.  There is a family history of heart disease – his father had a myocardial infarct at age 55.   Initial vital sign assessment reveals blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respirations 22 per minute  temperature 98.6 F  oxygen saturation 92% on room air.   Given Mr. Thompson's age  race  gender  multiple risk factors  presentation  and relevant past medical history  his clinical picture is highly concerning for acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency room with acute  severe  retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm that started 2 hours ago. Mr. Smith describes the pain as a heavy pressure  rating it 8 out of 10. He also reports shortness of breath  palpitations  lightheadedness  and nausea.  Past Medical History (PMH):  Mr. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia. He is an ex-smoker who quit 5 years ago but admits to having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His medication regimen includes Metformin 2000 mg per day for diabetes  Lisinopril 40 mg per day for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 40 mg per day for hyperlipidemia. He confessed to missing his medications for the past week due to financial difficulties. His last recorded Hemoglobin A1c level was 7.2  taken 6 months ago.  Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother has a history of type II diabetes and hypertension.  Social History:  He is retired and lives with his wife. He admits to drinking alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use. He denies regular physical activity and has a diet high in processed and fatty foods.  This is a typical presentation of an acute myocardial infarction in a patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors  including hypertension  type II diabetes  dyslipidemia  smoking history  and family history. It is consistent with the demographic representation of Caucasians and men being at a higher risk for an acute myocardial infarction. It also demonstrates the significance of uncontrolled risk factors and non-compliance with medication.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Harris  a 65-year-old African American male from Ohio  presented to the emergency room with acute  severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and diaphoresis. His pain started about three hours ago while he was doing gardening and has been progressively worsening. He mentions his pain at 9 on a scale of 10  described as a heavy crushing sensation. He has never experienced this type of pain before.  Past medical history (PMH): Mr. Harris has a ten-year history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  controlled with metformin and lisinopril respectively. He had a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia five years ago  for which he is taking simvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history  but quit smoking a year ago. There is a family history of coronary artery disease as his father suffered a heart attack at the age of 67.  Social history (SH): Retired banker  lives with his wife. He admits alcohol consumption socially.  Review of systems (ROS): Patient denied any prior similar episode  fever  cough  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Physical examination (PE): On examination  patient appeared anxious  pale  and sweaty. Vital signs: BP - 155/90 mm Hg  HR – 105/min  RR – 22/min  Temp - 98.6 F  SpO2 – 92% on room air. Cardiac exam revealed tachycardia without a heart murmur. Lung fields were clear on auscultation bilaterally. Abdominal exam was unremarkable. Extremities showed no edema.  This presentation suggests acute myocardial infarction  highly concerning for an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) given the sudden onset  severe pain  diaphoresis  and cardiovascular risk factors including advanced age  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  prior smoking  and family history. Further diagnostic studies such as ECG and cardiac enzymes  as well as immediate cardiology consultation  are warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Clark is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with a complaint of chest pain that began approximately six hours ago. His pain is described as intense pressure centrally located in his chest  radiating to his left arm. He states that it had begun suddenly while he was doing yard work. He also reports feeling short of breath  nauseous  sweaty  and lightheaded. His pain is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin  which his doctor prescribed for his diagnosed angina. He rates his pain as an 8 out of 10.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Clark has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and angina for which he is on medication. The patient has a 20-year history of cigarette smoking and he also states a sedentary lifestyle due to his 9-5 desk job. He has no known drug allergies.  Review of Literature:  The above case accurately represents the typical patient with an acute myocardial infarction as per the literature. Men  mainly those over the age of 60  are predisposed to ischemic heart disease. Hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus  smoking  and lack of physical activity are all common risk factors that contribute to the development of coronary artery disease and subsequent myocardial infarction. Additionally  symptoms such as chest pain  referred arm pain  associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating are frequently reported by patients experiencing an acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old Afro-American male named Mr. Smith reports to the Emergency Department (ED) of a local hospital at 3 pm. He describes experiencing central  crushing chest pain radiating down his left arm for the past four hours. The pain is graded 8 on the pain scale (0 being no pain and 10 being the most severe pain). Along with the chest pain  he has also been experiencing shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom.  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical record including Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which has been controlled by an oral hypoglycemic for the last 10 years. He has a 30-year history of sustained tobacco use but quit smoking five years ago. Although he has never been formally diagnosed with heart disease  his father died of a heart attack at 55 years of age. His lifestyle is primarily sedentary due to prolonged hours of desk work and he reports having a diet high in saturated fats.  He is currently not on any cardiovascular medication or aspirin. He denies having any allergies. His last meal was breakfast at 7 am this morning before leaving for work. His last regular bowel movement was yesterday. His history  along with the symptoms  indicates the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). His vital signs in the ED are Blood Pressure of 160/90 mmHg  Pulse 110 bpm  respiration rate of 22 bpm  Temperature 98.6 F  oxygen saturation at 94% on room air  and pain score of 8/10.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  Caucasian male  65 years old  is an active smoker with a 45-year pack history. He presents to the emergency department with persistent severe chest pain.  Chief Complaint: A severe crushing and burning chest pain that started two hours ago.  History of Present Illness: Two hours prior to entry  Mr. Doe says he experienced severe crushing and burning chest pain while doing yard work that radiated to the left arm and jaw. He describes it as unlike any previous chest discomfort he has had and rates it as 8 on a scale of 10. The pain is persistent and has not subsided with rest. He also reports feeling light-headed and experiencing mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a ten-year history of hypertension and high cholesterol. No history of previous myocardial infarction  but did have evidence of ischemic changes on a stress test two years prior that was treated conservatively.  Review of Systems: Positive for fatigue over the past few days  slight nausea  and decreased appetite.  Social History: Mr. Doe is retired and lives with his wife. He has been a smoker for over 45 years. His diet is high in red meat and saturated fats. He consumes alcohol minimally.   Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at age 67. His mother has a history of hypertension.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  pulse 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 19 breaths per minute. He appears sweaty and in distress. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia with S3 gallop. Pulmonary examination is unremarkable with clear breath sounds bilaterally. No lower extremity edema.  Based on patient history  physical exam  risk factors  and classic presentation  the primary concern is Acute Myocardial Infarction. The manager should immediately perform ECG and cardiac biomarkers for further assessment.

Chief Complaint: ""Severe chest pain radiating to the left arm since 2 hours.""  Patient Information:  58-year-old Hispanic/Latino male  body mass index of 31Kg/m2  a non-vegetarian with a 10-15 cigarettes per day smoking history for the past 20 years.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which are both moderately controlled with medications. There is a family history of ischemic heart disease  as his father died of a heart attack at age 65.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient describes a sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain that started 2 hours ago and has progressively worsened. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is accompanied by profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and a sensation of impending doom. He denies any nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient appears anxious and sweaty. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals a regular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Emergency department team has been alerted about the possible acute myocardial infarction and the patient is being prepared for immediate EKG  cardiac enzyme testing  and potentially a cardiac catheterization if warranted by the preliminary diagnostics.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain that has been ongoing for approximately three hours. The pain is described as ""crushing"" in nature  located centrally in his chest and radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reports associated symptoms of sweating  nausea and feeling generally unwell.  The patient has a past medical history significant for controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which he has had for approximately ten years. He is a current smoker (30-year pack history) and admits to lifestyle habits that include a diet high in saturated fats and low in fiber. He also states that his stress levels have been high recently due to work pressure. There is a known family history of cardiac diseases  with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  On physical examination  he appears pale  sweaty and anxious. His heart rate is 110 beats per minute and regular  blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.  His Electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  which are suggestive of an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction. His bedside troponin tests come back positive  confirming acute cardiac injury.  He is immediately administered aspirin  nitroglycerin and started on oxygen therapy as the emergency team preps for emergent coronary angiography. His case is further complicated by his risk factors which include age  diabetes  hypertension  smoking history  poor diet  ST-elevation on ECG  and positive troponin indicating a severe episode of myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Lopez  a 66-year-old Hispanic male  presents to emergency with a sudden onset of chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and jaw  accompanied by sweating and breathlessness lasting for 3 hours. He denies any recent trauma  fever  cough or other systemic symptoms. The chest pain is described as a burning sensation  severe in intensity  constant  and not relieved by rest.  Medical History:  Mr. Lopez has a well-documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last ten years  Hypertension for around eight years  and Dyslipidemia for approximately five years. His medications include Metformin 500 mg twice a day  Lisinopril 20 mg once a day  and Atorvastatin 40 mg daily at night. He also takes occasional Nitroglycerin sublingual tablets for previous complaints of chest discomfort.   He has an extensive family history of heart disease with his father having his first heart attack at the age of 58 and his mother passing away from a stroke at an early age. Mr. Lopez himself has been a smoker for the past 25 years  averaging one pack per day. He states that he does not exercise regularly due to his sedentary job and his diet is high in processed foods and low in vegetables and fruits.  He denies any previous similar episodes or hospitalizations. There are no known drug allergies. Review of Systems: He denies nausea  vomiting  recent weight loss  palpitations  or syncope.  Physical Examination: On general examination  the patient appears anxious and sweaty. Vitals include  BP: 160/90mm Hg  HR: 110 bpm  RR: 24 breaths per minute  Temperature: 98.6F  Oxygen Saturation: 95% on room air. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm  no murmur or additional heart sounds. Abdomen is soft  non-tender with no palpable masses. Peripheral pulses are regular and equal.  Note: Although women are greatly affected by heart diseases  the classic picture of acute myocardial infarction is more prevalent in men  particularly older men and more pronounced in those with existing comorbid conditions such as hypertension  diabetes and high cholesterol levels.

Subject: A 65-year-old African-American man  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain that started about two hours prior to arrival. The pain is centrally located and radiates to the left arm and jaw. The symptoms were accompanied by a sudden onset of dizziness  shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He also has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily  but quit 5 years ago. There is a family history of coronary heart disease  with his father having had a heart attack at age 70.  Social History: The patient is retired and lives with his wife of 40 years. He used to work as a factory worker but has been retired for five years. He has two adult children who live out of state. He denies illicit drug use  but admits to occasional alcohol use.   Physical examination: On examination  the patient appears uncomfortable with a pale complexion. He has an elevated heart rate (105 bpm)  blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg. Heart sounds reveal no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits.  Investigations: Laboratory tests and EKG were ordered immediately  and preliminary results show elevated levels of troponin and ST segment elevation on EKG  indicative of myocardial injury.  This clinical presentation is consistent with an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 63-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset of severe  crushing chest pain that radiated to his left arm and jaw. He describes the pain as 8/10  and it has lasted for approximately two hours. He also reports associated symptoms of diaphoresis  dyspnea  nausea  and light-headedness.  Demographics:  Mr. Smith is retired and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker who quit 8 years ago but has a 30-pack-year history. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and follows a diet high in saturated fats.  Relevant Past Medical History:   He has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are treated with medication. Furthermore  he mentions that his father had a heart attack at the age of 65.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith’s demographic and clinical presentation  family history of cardiac disease  and lifestyle factors place him at a high risk for acute myocardial infarction. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia are well-known risk factors for coronary artery disease  and his African American ethnicity  male sex  and age also place him in a demographic group with a heightened risk for heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department accompanied by his wife. The patient  named Mr. Brown  is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for the past 10 years. He has a 30-pack year smoking history. He was on metformin and lisinopril prescribed by his primary care physician.  Mr. Brown complained of sudden onset chest pain that started an hour ago while he was watching TV at home. He described the chest pain as ""heavy"" and ""pressing"" in nature  located centrally in the chest  rated it 8/10  and mentioned that it radiated to his left arm. The pain was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. He denied any relation of the pain with exertion or meals. He took a couple of antacids without any relief.   In addition to diabetes and hypertension  the family history reveals a strong predisposition to coronary artery disease - his father had a myocardial infarction in his late 50s.  On examination  Mr. Brown appeared distressed and diaphoretic  vital signs revealed blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  a pulse of 110 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 36.8 Degrees Celsius. Auscultation of the heart showed tachycardia without any added sounds and lungs were clear.  This case is of suspected Acute Myocardial Infarction based on the typical history and risk factors such as male gender  advanced age  smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and family history. The onset of pain at rest and association with symptoms like shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating further substantiate the suspicion. Measurement of cardiac biomarkers and an EKG will further confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes  and a 25-year pack smoking history presents to the emergency department with central chest pain  radiating to his left arm for the past 40 minutes during his morning walk. The pain is described as crushing and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  nausea  and profuse sweating. The pain was not relieved by rest. He denies similar episodes in the past and has no personal or family history of heart disease.  The patient reports that he has not taken his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications regularly for the last one month. He lives with his wife and has three grown-up children. He is retired and comes from a low-socioeconomic background.  The patient is calm  appears pale  and is in visible discomfort. He has a BMI of 30 and his vital signs are: Heart rate is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  respiratory rate is 20 and oxygen saturation is 94%. On physical examination  his cardiovascular system reveals a third heart sound.  He relates his dietary habit to be high in carbohydrates and fats and his exercise regime to be minimal. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies any known drug allergies. He has never undergone any surgical procedure in the past.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to Emergency Department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw that started about an hour ago. He describes the pain as a squeezing pressure  rated 8 out of 10 in intensity  and is somewhat relieved when he sits and leans forward. He also reports onset of shortness of breath  palpitations  and a feeling of apprehension.   Mr. Johnson is an active smoker with a 20-pack year smoking history. His past medical history is relevant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been compliant with his antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. He admits that he has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction in his mid-fifties.  On examination  Mr. Johnson appears pale and sweaty. His blood pressure is 175/95 mm Hg  the pulse rate is 110 beats/min  and respiratory rate is 21 breaths/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm without any added sounds or murmurs.  As per the available clinical data  these symptoms along with the risk factors such as age  male sex  race  smoking history  hypertension  family history of premature CHD  and diabetes  strongly suggest the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction.  Further evaluation  including an EKG and cardiac biomarkers  should be performed urgently to establish the diagnosis and initiate time-sensitive treatment. Patient's risk stratification  urgent reperfusion therapy  and prompt initiation of secondary preventive measures is vital in this case.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African American male with a medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia who reports to the emergency room complaining of sudden-onset  severe chest pain. The pain  described as ""crushing""  radiates to the left arm and jaw. Associated symptoms include diaphoresis  nausea and shortness of breath. The patient reports that the pain started about 1 hour ago  while he was engaged in moderate physical activity. He has never experienced something similar. Mr. Johnson is a smoker with a 20-pack year history. On arrival  his blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg and he appears anxious.  Mr. Johnson's father died of a heart attack at the age of 65 and her mother has had a history of angina. For his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  Mr. Johnson is taking Lisinopril and Simvastatin respectively  but is not regular with medications. He does not drink alcohol or use any other inappropriate substances.   His ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  and blood testing shows elevated cardiac biomarkers. Based on the clinical presentation  ECG and biomarker results  a diagnosis of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction is made.

Title: Case Study: A Multiethnic Presentation of Acute Myocardial Infarction  Slide 1: Introduction  Acute Myocardial Infarction refers to the death of a portion of the heart muscle (myocardium) owing to prolonged lack of oxygen supply (ischemia). It's a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide  affecting both genders and diverse ethnic groups.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  This case study focuses on a 62-year-old male patient of African American descent. Per recent studies  African Americans have a higher risk of developing heart disease compared to other ethnic groups. The disease also tends to present at younger ages in this population.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Key aspects in his past medical history include: 1. Hypertension  managed with medication. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus  poorly controlled. 3. Former smoker  who quit 10 years ago. 4. High Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.8  indicating obesity.  Slide 4: Hypertension and MI  Hypertension is a significant risk factor for MI. Our patient has a history of hypertension  making his heart work harder to pump blood  thereby increasing the risk of atherosclerosis - a common cause of MI.  Slide 5: Diabetes and MI  Poorly controlled diabetes  as in our patient's case  is associated with damage to the blood vessels  making the patient more vulnerable to atherosclerosis  and thereby  MI.  Slide 6: Smoking and MI  While our patient is a former smoker  the risk of MI does not disappear immediately after quitting. Increased vulnerability to MI can persist for years after quitting smoking.  Slide 7: Obesity and MI  Obesity raises the risk of heart disease by increasing the likelihood of high blood pressure  diabetes  and high cholesterol – all of which are risk factors for MI  as demonstrated in our patient.  Slide 8: Conclusion   Our patient’s ethnicity  along with his past medical history  paint a comprehensive picture of the risk factors for Acute Myocardial Infarction. Prompt diagnosis and administration of the suitable management strategy can greatly reduce morbidity and mortality.  References: 1. AHA. (2017). Heart Disease and Stroke Statistics-2017 At-a-Glance. 2. CDC. (2020). African American Health. 3. BMJ. (2013). Independent risk factors for acute myocardial infarction in smokers.

Presentation Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Middle-Aged Female Patient with Diabetes  Slide 1: Introduction Acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  commonly known as a heart attack  is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide  often related to cardiovascular diseases like hypertension  dyslipidemia  smoking  and diabetes.  Slide 2: Demographics and Epidemiology Patients most impacted by AMI are usually men over the age of 45 and women over the age of 55. However  it should be noted that demographic shifts over the past few decades have led to an increase in the burden of heart disease among women and younger adults. Today  we will discuss the case of a 52-year-old female patient who presented with an AMI.  Slide 3: Patient's History Our patient  Ms. S  a 52-year-old African American woman  with a past medical history significant for Type-2 diabetes and smoker for 15 years  presented to the emergency department with symptoms consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.  Slide 4: Medical History Ms. S has Type-2 diabetes for 17 years and hypertension for 9 years. She reported poor medication adherence due to financial constraints. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with her mother having died from a heart attack at age 60.  Slide 5: Presentation and Symptoms Ms. S reported sudden onset of severe chest pain  radiating down her left arm  with accompanying shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating. Her vitals on presentation were: Blood Pressure: 170/110 mmHg  Heart Rate: 110 bpm  Temperature: 37.4°C (99.3°F)  and O2 Sat: 92%.  Slide 6: Diagnostics An initial EKG indicated ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggestive of an inferior wall AMI. Blood tests revealed elevated cardiac enzymes. Her glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level was also elevated at 9.0%  reflecting poor blood sugar control.  Slide 7: Management and Outcome She was immediately started on the standard regime of aspirin  clopidogrel  an anticoagulant  and a statin. She underwent an urgent cardiac catheterization which confirmed a blockage in her right coronary artery and had a stent placed. Her post-procedure period was uneventful  and she was discharged home on the fifth day with advice for lifestyle modifications and medication regimen.  Slide 8: Discussion This case highlights the importance of considering AMI even in younger  female patients with cardiovascular risk factors. Managing such patients involves not only immediate treatment of AMI but also long-term management of associated conditions like diabetes and hypertension.  Slide 9: Conclusion This case emphasizes the need for better preventive strategies and patient education especially in population groups that have multiple risk factors including smoking  diabetes  hypertension  and a family history of coronary artery disease.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Middle-aged African American Female  Slide 1: Introduction  - Introduction to Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  also known as heart attack. - Demographic details highlighting its prevalence among middle-aged African American women  as studies suggest they face a disproportionate burden of cardiovascular diseases.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Introduction to our case: Ms. Johnson  a 52-year-old African American woman. - Career: High-stress job as an insurance adjuster - Height/Weight: Indicates possible obesity (BMI of 32) - Location: Urban resident  Slide 3: Clinical History  - Hypertension (high blood pressure) diagnosed 10 years ago  on medication but with inconsistent management. - Type II Diabetes diagnosed 5 years ago. - Smoker for 30 years (around 10 cigarettes daily).  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint  - Experience of sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck. - Accompanying symptoms: profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and feeling of impending doom. - Emergency services were called immediately.  Slide 5: Physical Examination & Diagnosis  - On examination  blood pressure was found to be elevated at 180/110 mmHg. - ECG showed ST segment elevation indicating acute myocardial infarction (STEMI). - Blood test: Elevated troponin levels which confirmed the diagnosis of AMI.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan & Management  - Immediate administration of aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen as initial emergency treatment. - Admitted to coronary care for further evaluation and management. - Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was done successfully. - Patient was put on ACE inhibitors  Beta-blockers  Statins  and Antiplatelet therapy  and advised for lifestyle changes including diet control  smoking cessation  and regular exercise.  Slide 7: Prognosis & Prevention  - Discussion on the prognosis and importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle. - Prevention focusing on managing modifiable risk factors like smoking  obesity  hypertension  and diabetes. - Importance of regular check-up  medication compliance and reduction of stress levels.   This case presentation underscores the need for proactive cardiovascular disease management  especially in high-risk demographics.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction  Acute Myocardial Infarction  also known as a heart attack  is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention by disrupting blood flow to the heart. Here is a case study elucidating the medical situation of a 62-year old African American male who experienced this condition.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male who works in a high-stress job. He is 5'10"" tall and weighs approximately 240 pounds. Lives urban with his wife and has 2 adult children. He engages in moderate alcohol consumption and is a regular smoker.  Slide 3: Epidemiological Relevance  As per American Heart Association  African American men above 60 are at higher risk of having a heart attack. Approximately 39% of African American men have some form of heart disease  largely due to risk factors like hypertension  obesity  and smoking  which are higher in this demographic.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  The patient has a history of Type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He stated that he has marginal control over these conditions and lacks regular exercise. Both his parents had heart disease and his father died of a heart attack at 67.  Slide 5: Current Medical Presentation  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm accompanied by shortness of breath  dizziness  and cold sweats which had begun approximately 1.5 hours prior to his arrival.   Slide 6: Diagnosis   Given the patient’s presenting symptoms  past medical history  and risk factors  he was diagnosed with Acute Myocardial Infarction based on EKG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes.   Slide 7: Treatment Plan  Treatment was begun immediately with aspirin  nitroglycerin and morphine for pain control. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention was performed  with placement of a stent in his right coronary artery. He was then initiated on a regimen of dual antiplatelet therapy  high-intensity statins  and ACE inhibitors.  Slide 8: Prognosis & Follow-Up  With consistent medication  lifestyle alterations and routine follow-up  he can expect a substantial improvement in his condition. Emphasis is placed on smoking cessation  improved diet  participation in a cardiac rehabilitation program  and stress management techniques.  Slide 9: Conclusion  This case study elucidates the critical recognition of risk factors  prompt diagnosis  and intervention in the management of Acute Myocardial Infarction. It is crucial to stress preventive strategies and regular health screenings among high-risk demographics.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Case Study  Slide 1: Title - Patient Demographics - Gender: Male - Age: 58 years - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Note: Demographically  the majority of acute myocardial infarction cases in the U.S. are found in Caucasian males over the age of 45  according to the American Heart Association.  Slide 2: Title - Lifestyle and Social History - Sedentary Lifestyle: Works as an accountant with long hours of desk work  minimal physical activity. - Social History: Social drinker  smoked for 20 years but quit 7 years ago. - Diet: High in saturated fats and processed foods. - Stress: High job stress. Note: Sedentary lifestyle  unhealthy diet  smoking  and stress are significant risk factors for acute myocardial infarction.   Slide 3: Title - Past Medical History - Hypertension: Diagnosed six years ago; on medication. - Diabetes: Diagnosed three years ago; on oral hypoglycemic agents. - Hypercholesterolemia: On statins intermittently. Note: Hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia are major medical risk factors for acute myocardial infarction. Irregular medication habits may exacerbate these conditions.  Slide 4: Title - Family History - Father: Died of acute myocardial infarction at age 62. - Brother: Diagnosed with angina at age 55. Note: Genetic factors significantly contribute to the risk of developing heart disease.  Slide 5: Title - Current Complaint - Chest Pain: Started experiencing severe chest pain  described as a heavy pressure  radiating to the left arm. - Other Symptoms: Shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. Note: These are typical symptoms of acute myocardial infarction  mandating immediate medical attention.  Slide 6: Title - Investigations & Diagnosis - ECG: Indicative of ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). - Blood Tests: Elevated troponin levels. - Coronary Angiogram: Revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Diagnosis: Acute Myocardial Infarction. Note: Elevation in ST segments  increased troponin levels  and stenosis in coronary arteries confirm diagnosis of AMI.   Slide 7: Title - Treatment and Management - Immediate: Administered aspirin  nitroglycerin  and started on a heparin drip. - Reperfusion Therapy: Underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to restore blood flow in the blocked artery. - Long-term Management: Lifestyle modifications advised and started on medication (beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  statins). Note: Prompt identification and reperfusion therapy  followed by adequate secondary prevention measures  are critical to improve survival rates.  Slide 8: Title - Prognosis & Education - With adherence to recommended lifestyle changes and medication  prognosis can be significantly improved. - Importance of regular follow-up and cardiac rehabilitation emphasized. - Patient and family educated on the importance of early recognition of heart attack symptoms for timely intervention.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in an Elderly African American Male   I. Patient Demographics - Age: 72 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired (former factory worker) - Substantially under-resourced  lives alone in a city environment.  II. Past Medical History - Hypertensive: Diagnosed at age 59.  - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed at age 63.  - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed at age 67. - Reports intermittent chest pain but ascribed it to ""indigestion."" - No history of surgical admissions or known allergies. - Smoked half a pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years but quit 10 years ago.  III. Presenting Complaint  - The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  commencing earlier in the day while the patient was resting.  - Describes chest pain as ""a heavy crushing sensation"" along with shortness of breath.  IV. Examination and Diagnosis  - On physical examination  the patient appears sweaty and distressed. - Blood pressure: 180/95 mmHg | Heart rate: 110 bpm | Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute. - Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation indicative of myocardial ischemia.  - Blood tests (troponin levels) further confirmed the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (MI).  Discussion:  This case represents a typical AMI scenario in the light of risk factors such as hypertensive heart disease  age  male gender  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. African American men have been reported to have a higher risk for MI- particularly in those aged 65 to 74 years. This demographic also demonstrates significant social determinants of health that affect their MI management  including access to care  health behavior attitudes  and compliance. This patient's delay in seeking care is a common issue in this demographic and highlights the importance of public education to recognize the signs and symptoms of an MI and seek immediate care.   The management of this patient included urgent revascularisation via percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) alongside with antithrombotic therapy  management of his hypertension and diabetes  risk factors reduction strategies including promoting lifestyle modifications like diet exercise and regular follow-ups.   This case emphasizes the importance of managing chronic conditions  recognizing symptoms early  lifestyle modifications and comprehensive  culturally competent care in preventing disease progression and future cardiac events.  Source: National Center for Biotechnology Information. (2020). Acute myocardial infarction Case Study. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7534554/

Slide 1: Introduction This case presentation revolves around the real-life clinical scenario of acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  also known as a heart attack. It is meant to emphasize the importance of accurate and timely diagnosis and treatment in this high-stake situation.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics The patient in our case is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC)  men are more likely to have heart attacks  and they occur earlier in life. The average age at the first heart attack is 65.6 years for males.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Our patient has a significant past medical history which includes hypertension  type II diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia. He is an ex-smoker but quit smoking ten years ago. The patient's father experienced a fatal MI at the age of 55. All these conditions place our patient into a higher-than-average risk category for acute myocardial infarction.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints The patient came to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and shoulder. The pain started approximately 2 hours back while the patient was cutting wood. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  nausea  and expressed feeling of impending doom.   Slide 5: Clinical Overview Upon physical examination  our patient showed signs of anxiety and distress  pale  clammy skin  and elevated blood pressure. His Electrocardiogram (ECG) changes strongly suggested acute myocardial infarction.  Slide 6: Diagnosis & Investigations Confirmation of an acute myocardial infarction is done using clinical findings  ECG changes and elevated cardiac biomarkers. In this case  our patient's troponin levels were significantly raised.  Slide 7: Treatment Our patient was given immediate antiplatelet therapy  nitro-glycerine for chest pain  beta blockers to slow down heart rate  oxygen to alleviate his shortness of breath  and morphine for pain management.   Slide 8: Conclusion Our patient was promptly sent to the cardiac catheterization lab for primary percutaneous coronary intervention. This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the risk factors and early symptoms of Acute Myocardial Infarction for timely and efficient management.  Slide 9: Public Health Consideration Given the rise in lifestyle diseases and risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes and smoking  it becomes crucial to educate the public about heart health and awareness  and the benefits of early intervention and risk factor modification.

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction - Case Study  Slide 1:   Title: Patient Demographics  • Patient Profile: Male  Age 65 • Ethnicity: Caucasian  • Occupation: Retired engineer  • Location: Urban area  • Socio-Economic Status: Middle Class  Slide 2:  Title: Risk Factors  • Lifestyle: Former smoker; quit 5 years ago; occasional alcohol intake • Body Mass Index (BMI): 28.6 Kg/m² - Overweight • Family History: Father died of heart disease at age 70  Slide 3:  Title: Past Medical History  • Diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  on metformin • Hypertension for 15 years  on amlodipine • Previous diagnosis of hypercholesterolemia  treated with statins  Slide 4:  Title: Presenting Complaint  • Acute onset chest pain  severe and crushing in nature • Associated symptoms: Sweating  shortness of breath and feeling of impending doom  Slide 5:   Title: Examination and Investigation Findings  • Elevated Troponin I levels and changes in ECG suggestive of acute myocardial infarction • Echo findings: Reduced ejection fraction (40%)  Slide 6:  Title: Hospital Course  • Immediate reperfusion strategy implemented • Received thrombolytic therapy as per protocol • Stabilized during hospital stay and discharged on beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  statins and low-dose aspirin  Slide 7:  Title: Follow-Up Care  • Strict glycemic control advised • Healthy diet  regular exercise and weight management emphasized • Regular cardiac rehab sessions planned  Slide 8:  Title: Conclusion  • This case underscores the importance of proactive primary care to prevent accelerating cardiovascular disease  • Exercise  diet  medication adherence  and regular check-ups are crucial for such patients  (Note: While minor variations occur globally  the risks for myocardial infarction have been shown to increase with age  especially among men. Caucasians are proven to be at slightly higher risk  and existing conditions like diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a family history of heart disease  significantly contribute to the risk.)

Title: Case Presentation on Acute Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack)   Slide 1: Introduction   Today  we're going to discuss a case of a male patient diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  also known as a heart attack.  Slide 2: Demographics  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male. According to the American Heart Association  heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States  with African American men being disproportionately affected.   Slide 3: Past Medical History   Our patient has a history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 10mg daily. Also  he has Type 2 diabetes for the past eight years  controlled with metformin. He is a former smoker (stopped 10 years ago) but continues to maintain a relatively sedentary lifestyle. Family history reveals his father having a heart attack at age 56.   Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  The patient presented at the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started while he was mowing his lawn. It’s been described as a ‘crushing’ sensation  radiating to his left arm and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath. These symptoms have persisted for more than two hours.
