He also has a family history of early coronary artery disease  with his father dying unexpectedly from a heart attack at age 55. On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. His blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 100 bpm  and he has normal oxygen saturation levels. His physical examination is normal  with no abnormalities heard on auscultation of the heart. His EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggestive of an inferior-wall myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 63-year-old male with history of smoking and hypertension  who presents with crushing chest pain that radiated to his left jaw and shoulder. He notes the pain began suddenly while walking his dog and describes it as the worst pain he has ever felt. The pain has been continuous for the past 45 minutes. He reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. Furthermore  patient mentions he had similar pain a week ago while climbing stairs  which resolved after few minutes of rest. Patient has not taken any medications prior to presentation. Patient's father had a history of myocardial infarction at the age of 65. Patient's BP: 160/95mmhg  Pulse rate: 105 bpm  RR: 22 breaths/min  Temp: 37.1°C. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V6  suggesting acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient is immediately started on a regimen of ASA  nitroglycerin  beta-blockers  and heparin  with arrangement for urgent coronary angiography per protocol for early intervention in ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI).

Problem Representation:  A 56-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of smoking for the past 30 years  obesity (BMI 31)  and uncontrolled hypertension  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe chest pain for the last 2 hours. The pain is described as retrosternal  heavy pressure-like  radiating to his left arm and jaw. It started while he was sleeping and has been constant since. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and palpitations. He denied any nausea  vomiting  or lightheadedness. His electronic health records indicate non-compliance to antihypertensive medications. He reports no known history of diabetes or hyperlipidemia and denies any family history of coronary artery disease. His chest pain is not alleviated by nitroglycerin under the tongue. His blood pressure on presentation is 170/100 mmHg  pulse rate is 112/min  and oxygen saturation is 92%. Initial physical examination is significant for an anxious  sweaty  obese male in distress. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. EKG shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF  which indicates an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. His troponin levels are awaited.

Patient Description: A 65-year-old Caucasian male retired dock worker from a lower socioeconomic background.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and is a smoker with 30-pack years. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication. There is a family history of heart disease  with his father having died of a heart attack at age 64. He consumes alcohol socially and has a diet high in saturated fats. He has no known history of diabetes or hypercholesterolemia. He is generally sedentary and does not engage in regular exercise.  Presentation: The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm  ensuing for approximately one hour. He reports feeling nauseated  lightheaded  and experiencing cold sweat. He characterizes the pain as being unlike anything he has felt before. His vital signs on presentation are blood pressure 160/100 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  respiration 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  and temperature 36.9 degree Celsius.  Initial EKG suggests ST elevations in anterior leads and cardiac enzymes are pending. These symptoms appear to be consistent with an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (heart attack). The patient is immediately assessed for potential thrombolytic therapy.

Problem Representation:  Mr. James  a 65-year-old African American male with a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia and type II diabetes  and social history of smoking and alcohol use  presents to the emergency room with crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and shoulder. The pain initiated an hour ago and has progressively worsened. Alongside  he is also experiencing shortness of breath even at rest  diaphoresis  nausea and sense of impending doom. On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. His vitals show tachycardia  and blood pressure is 160/90mm Hg. His electrocardiogram shows ST segment elevation in inferior leads suggesting an acute inferior myocardial infarction. His troponin levels are elevated. Mr. James weight and BMI indicates mild obesity. He admits to not following a proper diet or exercise regime and does not closely manage his diabetes  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. He is frequently non-compliant to medications  partly because of economic factors. His family history is significant with his father and elder brother having history of coronary artery disease.   This clinical picture is typical for acute myocardial infarction  common in male patients over 60 and frequent in African American population. Relevant risk factors include persistent uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes  smoking  obesity  non-compliance to medication  age  and family history of coronary artery disease.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American male was referred to the emergency department due to severe chest pain. He describes the pain as central  heavy  and radiating to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include overwhelming fatigue  dyspnea  and sudden breaking sweats. The symptoms started approximately 3 hours ago while he was at rest.  His past medical history is significant for Type II Diabetes Mellitus  well controlled on metformin for the last 10 years  essential hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and losartan  and hyperlipidemia managed with simvastatin. He is a current smoker with 45 pack-years of tobacco use and reports a sedentary lifestyle. His family history is notable for an elder brother who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 years. He denies any recent use of recreational stimulants.  This presentation is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. Given the patient’s age  racial background  male sex  smoking history  family history  and multiple cardiovascular risk factors  these demographics align with epidemiological data correlating highest risk of acute myocardial infarction.

Problem Representation:  A 64-year-old Hispanic male patient presents to the emergency room displaying symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction. Roughly 45 minutes prior to arrival  the patient began experiencing severe chest discomfort described as an intense crushing pressure that radiates to the arm and jaw. Accompanying the chest pain are diaphoresis  dyspnea  and feelings of lightheadedness. The patient has a known history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking habit he gave up ten years ago. The patient has not been taking his prescribed medications (metformin and atorvastatin) regularly due to some financial issues. He reports there has been a lot of stress recently due to a family bereavement.   The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father having experienced an MI at the age of 59. The patient is profoundly anxious due to his knowledge of family history and own medical conditions. On immediate evaluation  he appeared pale  was diaphoretic  and displayed signs of respiratory distress with an elevated heart rate and blood pressure documenting 110 bpm and 160/100 mmHg respectively.

Demographic Information:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker with a 30-pack-year smoking history. He has a past medical history notable for untreated hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His family history is significant for ischemic heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at 58. Mr. Smith is not on any current medication and declares inconsistent medical follow-up.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Smith presents to the ER with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw for the past two hours. The pain is severe (8/10) and is associated with dyspnea  diaphoresis  and nausea. The pain is primarily midsternal and pressure-like in quality. He denies recent illnesses  fever  chills  cough  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema.  Given his risk factors (race  smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  family history of early coronary artery disease) and classic presentation  Mr. Smith’s symptoms are highly concerning for an acute myocardial infarction.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a history of hypertension and diabetes  presents to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain is severe  crushing  associated with shortness of breath  profuse diaphoresis  nausea  and light-headedness. The patient reports immediate onset while lifting heavy objects earlier. There's no history of illicit drug use. His father died at the age of 58 due to a heart attack. The symptoms started 1 hour before presenting to the ED. Upon arrival  blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate is irregular and rapid at 110 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. His electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevations in leads II  III  and aVF suggestive of acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. Troponin T was elevated above normal range. The patient is currently on metformin for his diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old African American male  retired construction worker with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and smoking presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  crushing chest pain that he describes as ""sitting on his chest"" for the last 60 minutes. The pain is radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reports accompanying symptoms of nausea  profuse sweating and shortness of breath. He has no known allergies. The patient does not have a personal history of heart disease  but his father had a myocardial infarction in his early 70s. He is currently taking metformin for his diabetes and amlodipine for his hypertension. The patient also has a 45-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. No recent changes in diet or activity level. Physical examination reveals the patient to be in severe distress with observable pallor and diaphoresis. His blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  and respiratory rate 22/min. Heart sounds are regular without any murmur or rub. No jugular venous distention  lungs are clear on auscultation  and his pulses are equal and symmetric in all four extremities. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Information:   A 62-year-old Caucasian male who works in a high-stress environment as a finance executive.   Medical History:   The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes anti-hypertensives and statins. He has a 20-pack year smoking history  and his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He also has a sedentary lifestyle and a BMI of 30.5. He is non-diabetic and does not have any known drug allergies.  Presentation:   This patient presents with central chest pain of 2 hours duration which he describes as a 'heaviness'  radiating to the left arm. He also states he has been feeling nauseated  sweaty and extremely anxious. Furthermore  he reported a similar  but milder chest discomfort during an executive meeting 1 week ago that resolved spontaneously.   Impression:  Given the patient's age  history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  strong family history of heart disease  smoking history  prolonged sedentary behaviour  past (but ignored) instance of similar condition  and the classic symptoms of chest pain radiating to the arm with associated symptoms like anxiety  sweating  and nausea  there is high suspicion of an acute myocardial infarction.    Plan:  Immediate EKG  cardiac marker test (troponins)  chest X-ray  and if necessary  a coronary angiogram to confirm diagnosis. The patient should be kept under observation in the ICU while symptom management with aspirin  nitroglycerin  and oxygen should be started. This situation warrants immediate medical attention and possibly urgent revascularization by PCI or thrombolysis. When stable  the patient would benefit from education about lifestyle modification such as dietary changes  regular exercise  stress management  smoking cessation  weight management  and stricter control of his blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Williams  a 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden-onset severe chest pain. The pain is described as crushing in nature  radiating to his left arm and jaw  accompanied by sweating and shortness of breath. He reports the pain began while he was mowing the lawn. Previous episodes of angina have been reported but were relieved with rest and nitroglycerin. However  the severity and persistence of this episode is unusual and has lasted for more than 30 minutes. His medications include Metformin for diabetes  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and Lisinopril for hypertension. The patient is a smoker of 20 years  and he reports moderate alcohol consumption. His father died of a heart attack in his early 70s. The patient's vitals on arrival are pulse 100/min  blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg  respiration 18/min. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads  suggesting an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction.

A 68-year-old African American male patient  retired construction worker  presents to the ER with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm which started one hour ago while resting at home. He rates his pain as 8 out of 10  describing it as a crushing sensation. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  sweating  and nausea. His medical history is significant for hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with 40 pack-years and is currently on metformin for diabetes  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and lisinopril for hypertension. There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease; his father had a heart attack at age 60. On physical examination  he appeared acutely ill and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  heart rate 100bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung auscultation was clear. EKG showed ST-segment elevations in leads II  III and aVF suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Mr. Robert Thompson  a 63-year-old African American male with a known medical history of unmanaged type II diabetes  hypertension  and familial hyperlipidemia  presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. The pain began approximately 2 hours prior to his arrival and is associated with diaphoresis  light-headedness  dyspnea  and a sense of impending doom. He is a one-pack-per-day smoker for 40 years and leads a sedentary lifestyle with a largely high fat  high cholesterol diet. He has ignored symptoms indicative of angina for the past few weeks  misattribiting them to indigestion. Family history is significant for premature cardiovascular disease; his father passed away due to a heart attack at age 55. His BP on presentation is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate is 105 bpm and respirations are 24 per minute. An EKG indicates ST-segment elevations suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.

Mr. Davis is a 63-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which have been managed with medications for the past 15 years; he is also an active smoker with a 30-pack year history and an alcoholic  consuming about eight to ten standard drinks per week. He presents to the emergency department complaining of a severe  crushing central chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck that started two hours ago while mowing the lawn  and is associated with profuse sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. He denies any recent episodes of cough  fever  GI upset  or urinary symptoms. Vital signs on presentation show blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  heart rate of 100 beats per minute  respirations 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 95% on room air. Initial EKG demonstrates ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads  indicative of an acute anterior-lateral myocardial infarction. A troponin level was also drawn and is pending.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a 10-year history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency department with severe retrosternal chest pain. The pain began 2 hours ago  is persistent  and is described as a ""heavy pressure."" The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He is a retired truck driver; his family history is significant for coronary artery disease with his father undergoing bypass surgery at age 63. He has no known drug allergies; his medications include aspirin (81mg daily)  metformin (500mg twice daily)  and lisinopril (10mg daily).  In the emergency department  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 85 bpm  temperature is 98.6°F  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is at 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic and anxious man in distress  with no significant findings otherwise. His 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads  suggesting an acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction. Initial labs  including troponin-I  are pending. The patient is currently receiving oxygen  nitroglycerin  and has been administered a loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel. An emergency cardiology consultation has been requested for likely primary percutaneous coronary intervention.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: Documented history of smoking for the past 40 years  high blood pressure  high cholesterol levels  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has not been adhering to prescribed antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports sudden onset crushing chest pain  radiating down the left arm  and difficulty in breathing. The pain is described as 9/10 and began approximately 45 minutes prior to arrival.  On Presentation: On physical examination  he is diaphoretic and looks very uncomfortable. Heart rate: 105 beats per minute  Blood pressure: 145/90 mmHg  Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute  SpO2: 92% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals an irregular rhythm with an S4 gallop and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung exam reveals bibasilar crackles. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable.  The patient's clinical picture is suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction. The reported chest pain  its radiation towards the left arm  associated shortness of breath  known history of risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia and tobacco use all point towards this diagnosis.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Anderson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. This pain is atypical and no previous instances have been reported.   Relevant Past Medical History:  His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and an occasional heavy drinker. He is also overweight (BMI 29). His father died of a heart attack at age 62. Patient is currently on antihypertensive and antilipidemic medications.  Relevant Symptoms on Presentation:   Besides the severe chest pain  he also complains of shortness of breath  sweating  and a sense of impending doom. He rates the pain as 8 out of 10  describing it as a pressure sensation located centrally in the chest and radiating to the left arm. The pain is not relieved by rest or by taking his regular nitroglycerine tablets. His blood pressure is 140/96 and pulse is 98 bpm. His face is pale  he appears uncomfortable  and there are cold sweats visible.  This presentation is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction  considering his age  race  medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and the significant cardiac risk factors including smoking  family history of heart disease and obesity. Immediate medical evaluation and management are critical for this patient. This will begin with an electrocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the myocardial infarction.

Patient: Mr. John  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  currently retired  non-smoker.   Presenting problem: Mr. John came to the ER with acute onset of severe central chest pain described as a pressing sensation  radiating to his left arm and jaw  associated with shortness of breath  sweating and feeling of impending doom. The pain began around 2 hours ago while he was gardening. On a scale of 1-10  he reported pain as a 9.  Relevant medical history: The patient has known hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both diagnosed 10 years ago and under control with amlodipine and metformin  respectively. His father had a fatal heart attack at the age of 68.  Physical examination: Upon assessment  patient appeared in distress  was diaphoretic  and had irregular heartbeat. Blood pressure showed 150/90 mmHg and pulse rate 102 bpm. Chest auscultation revealed normal lung sounds  but EKG was indicative of ST-elevation in leads II  III  and AVF  suggesting possible inferior wall myocardial infarction.   In conclusion: The patient is presenting with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)  potentially due to chronic untreated risk factors such as hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. The patient needs immediate treatment urgently for his condition.

Patient: A 67-year-old African American male.  Relevant Medical History: History of poorly controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both being managed with medication for the past 10 years. Patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years. There is family history of cardiovascular disease as the patient's father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 63.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient reports intense chest pain of sudden onset  described as ""squeezing"" in nature and radiating to left arm and jaw  that has lasted for over an hour. Associated symptoms include sweating  light-headedness and shortness of breath. Patient reports no relief with rest.  Emergency department records reveal that patient has an elevated heart rate  elevated blood pressure and oxygen saturation of 90%. An EKG shows ST segment elevations consistent with an acute anterior myocardial infarction. The patient was immediately transferred to the cardiac care unit and preparations were made to initiate reperfusion therapy. Blood tests were ordered  including complete blood count  cardiac markers  blood glucose  electrolytes  and lipid profile.

Patient Identification: Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Relevant Medical History: Mr. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  both of which are managed with medication. He also has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 60.  Current Presentation: Mr. Smith was brought to the emergency room with a sharp chest pain of sudden onset while he was resting at home. The pain was described as heavy in nature and did not lessen with rest. The pain also radiates to his left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of light-headedness. His vitals at presentation included blood pressure at 160/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm.  Setting: This is taking place in the emergency room where Mr. Smith is being evaluated for his symptoms.   Problem Representation: Mr. Smith presents with symptoms suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction  possibly superimposed on his pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension  dyslipidemia  and smoking history).

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African-American male  Medical History: The patient has a long-time history of type II diabetes and hypertension. He is also a current smoker with a 40 pack-year history.  Problem Representation: The patient presented to the emergency room with a complaint of severe  crushing discomfort in his chest  which started an hour ago and has been constantly persisting. The pain also radiates to his left arm and jaw. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  sweating  and light-headedness. Upon examination  his blood pressure is high at 160/90 mmHg and heart rate is increased at 110 bpm. His EKG reveals ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads  indicating an anterior wall myocardial infarction. A subsequent lab test confirms elevated cardiac enzymes (troponin I and CK-MB). Given the patient's symptomatic and diagnostic presentation  his clinical condition is determined as acute myocardial infarction. His high-risk factors include age  ethnicity  diabetes  hypertension  and smoking.

Patient Presentation: Mr. James  a 65-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  current smoker  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus.   Presenting Complaint: He presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  that began while he was at rest today. Symptoms were accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a sense of impending doom.  Vital Signs/Physical Examination: BP 160/95  Heart rate 110 bpm and regular  Respiratory rate 25 per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Examination finds him to be in severe distress  with cold and clammy skin. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia and no heart murmurs. Chest auscultation showed reduced breath sounds in the lower left lung. He has a BMI of 30  indicating obesity.  Approximately 2/3 of heart attacks occur in people over the age of 65  and African Americans are more likely to have serious complications  such as heart failure or death  from a heart attack. In the general population  men are more likely than women to have heart attacks  and they typically occur at a younger age in men than women. However  rates of heart attack are increasing among women  particularly younger women.

A 62-year-old male patient with a medical history of type II diabetes and hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with an adjoining complaint of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain started about two hours ago while he was mowing the lawn and has been persistent. It is described as a heavy crushing pain  situated in the middle of the chest. The patient also mentions experiencing episodes of such chest pain during exertion in the past few weeks but they usually resolved with rest  which he dismissed as gastrointestinal in origin. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweats. Past medical history investigation reveals that he is a pack-a-day smoker for the past 35 years and has a strong family history of premature cardiovascular disease. The patient is not on any daily medications and denies any known drug allergies. He consumed alcohol socially and doesn't report any illicit drug usage. With these risk factors  symptoms  and his medical history  the preliminary diagnosis suggests an acute myocardial infarction.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old African American male  BMI of 30  with a medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which he takes Metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril  presents with crushing chest pain  radiating to the left arm  which started while walking his dog. The pain was sudden in onset and has lasted for about 45 minutes. The patient also reports associated shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and feeling of impending doom. He has a 20 pack-year history of tobacco use and his father died of a heart attack at age 65.  Upon physical examination  the patient appears diaphoretic and anxious. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. There are no other significant findings on physical examination.  The case presentation is suggestive of Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI).   Demographic statistics for myocardial infarction help inform that men  particularly African American men  are more at risk  as are individuals with obesity  uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Family history further elevates this patient's risk.

A 67-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  type-2 diabetes mellitus  and 30-pack year smoking presents to the emergency department with acute onset  severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw for the past 2 hours. Accompanying symptoms include diaphoresis (excessive sweating)  nausea  and shortness of breath. He has no known allergies  and his medications include hydrochlorothiazide  lisinopril  and metformin. Patient's mother and father had histories of heart disease and both suffered myocardial infarctions in their late 60s. His vital signs on presentation are blood pressure: 170/90 mmHg  heart rate: 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute  temperature: 98°F (36.7°C) and oxygen saturation: 92% on room air. A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads  consistent with an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient presents with a history of hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  which he quit 5 years ago. A recent lipid panel indicated hyperlipidemia  which is being managed with statins. Additionally  Johnson has a family history of early-onset cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Problem: For the last four hours  Mr. Johnson has been experiencing sudden and severe chest pain  described as ""crushing"" and radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reports associated symptoms of profuse sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. Mr. Johnson has never experienced similar symptoms before and the onset was while he was resting. He rates his pain as an 8 out of 10.  Physical Examination: Mr. Johnson appears anxious. He is overweight with a Body Mass Index of 32. His blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  pulse is 102 beats per minute  and he is wheezing on auscultation.  Given his symptoms and history  the working diagnosis is an acute myocardial infarction. Immediate medical attention is required for further investigation and management.

Demographics: A 65-year-old Caucasian male   Presenting Complaint: Crushing central chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw that started at rest early in the morning  Past Medical History: Known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia; history of heavy tobacco use; family history of early sudden cardiac death in a brother (died from a heart attack at age 60)  Physical Examination: Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  temperature of 37 degrees Celsius  with oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On examination  patient appears anxious and sweaty. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological exams are unremarkable.  Relevant Symptoms: Chest pain is severe  as if ""an elephant is sitting on the chest""  lasting more than 30 minutes and not easing with rest. Pain is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. No change in positional nature of the pain  no radiation to the right arm nor pain on deep inspiration.   Diagnostic Impressions: Based on the patient's presentation and history  a strong clinical suspicion of acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is present. Immediate 12-lead ECG  cardiac enzyme testing  and consultation with cardiology for potential acute intervention are warranted.

Problem Representation:  George is a 61-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the Emergency Department with acute severe central chest pain radiating to his left arm. The pain onset was sudden  two hours ago while he was eating breakfast and has persisted since then. He describes the pain as a crushing and severe  rated at an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale  and he is sweaty and pale. He has been feeling nauseous and short of breath also.  George has been a smoker for over 30 years and drinks alcohol socially. He has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  both of which are being treated with oral medication. However  he admits that he has been non-compliant with his diet and medication recently. His father also died of a heart attack in his sixties.  On examination  George appears anxious and distressed. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  temperature is normal  heart rateis 110 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs or extra heart sounds.  Given the patient's history  presentation and risk factors  acute myocardial infarction is suspected.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Presenting Complaint: He comes in complaining of sudden central chest pain that has persisted for two hours. This pain is described as severely pressing or squeezing in nature  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include nausea  vomiting  sweating  and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Over the past ten years  the patient has been managing type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. There is also a family history of early heart disease  with his father suffering a heart attack at age 55. The patient is an ex-smoker but quit 5 years ago; however  he confesses to regular alcohol consumption and a sedentary lifestyle.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient looks pale  sweaty  and anxious. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 110 bpm  and a respiratory rate of 24 per minute. Heart sounds are rapid but rhythmic with no audible murmurs. Chest examination reveals no rales  and rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Impression: Acute ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)  with relevant risk factors being age  male sex  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  family history of heart disease  and lifestyle factors.

Patient Information:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department.   Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus that have been controlled with medication. He also has a 40-pack-year smoking history which he quit 5 years ago.  Chief Complaint:  The patient reports experiencing severe chest pain that started a couple of hours ago. The pain is central  radiating to the jaw and left arm. He describes it as a heavy pressure-like sensation. Accompanying symptoms include diaphoresis  palpitations  shortness of breath  and nausea.  On examination  the patient appears pale and is sweating. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respirations 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Lung sounds reveal no crackles or wheezes.  Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction. Initial lab work including troponin levels is pending.   In the context of the patient's clinical presentation  personal medical history  lifestyle factors  and ECG changes  the leading diagnosis is acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presented with sudden-onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw  associated with dizziness  sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath. Symptoms began while the patient was gardening  approximately 2 hours prior to presentation. The pain is described as heavy pressure and rated 8 out of 10. The patient is a 20-pack year smoker and has a family history of early heart disease. His medications include Metformin for his diabetes and Hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He has no known drug allergies. On presentation  the patient was in obvious distress with pale  cool  clammy skin. Vital signs showed blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F  and Oxygen saturation 95% on room air. First EKG shows ST segment elevations in the anterior-septal leads  suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old African American male presents with an acute onset of severe  crushing chest pain that started 2 hours prior to his arrival at the emergency department. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking. He tells you he has never experienced anything like this before. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg  pulse rate is 92 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. The rest of his physical exams  including cardiovascular  abdominal  and lung exams are unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST elevation in the anterior leads  indicative of a possible anterior wall myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  associated with profuse sweating and dyspnea. Pain onset was roughly 2 hours ago  characterized as a crushing sensation. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history. There is a significant past medical history of hypertension that has been suboptimally controlled over the past 10 years. His father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 60. He denies any illicit drug use. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic and anxious male with central chest tenderness. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation  suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

A 62-year-old  Caucasian male  known smoker with a 40 pack-year history  presents to the emergency department with acute  severe  and crushing retrosternal chest pain of 2-hour duration  radiating to his left arm. The pain was associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.   The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. His father had myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He has no known allergies.   On examination  he seems in distress with a BP of 155/95  heart rate of 110 bpm  and mild tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed an irregular rhythm with no extra heart sounds or murmurs. Lung fields were clear on auscultation. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Based on the age  gender  relevant life habits  associated risk factors and the nature of the clinical presentation  the patient is highly likely to be suffering from an acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history presents to the emergency department complaining of severe crushing  substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm that started about 3 hours ago. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. He also reports episodes of similar but less severe pain over the past week. He admits to significant stress at work recently. He denies having any similar episodes in the past. He denies illicit drug use and does not have any family history of premature coronary artery disease. On examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. He is afebrile but has a slightly elevated blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg and a resting heart rate of 105 beats per minute. His cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the examination including neurological is normal. His EKG in the ED reveals ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads. Blood analysis showed elevated cardiac enzymes. The patient’s symptoms  history  examinations  and investigations suggest an acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile: 65-year-old African American male.   Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-2 diabetes that have been managed with medication. He is a 45 pack-year smoker  and he admits dietary habits are high in fats and cholesterol. He has no known family history of heart disease.  Presenting Problem: The patient presented to the emergency department with chest discomfort of acute onset (2 hours duration) that he describes as a pressing/squeezing pain in the center of his chest radiating to his left arm. The pain has not been relieved by rest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis (excessive sweating)  and mild nausea. An EKG shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  Relevant Symptoms: Acute-onset chest pain  shortness of breath  diaphoresis  mild nausea  and left arm pain.  Problem Representation: This is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type-2 diabetes  and long-term cigarette smoking who presents with an acute onset chest pain  diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath  suggestive of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a high-stress occupation  presents with symptoms consistent with Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI). The patient is a known case of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both managed with medication. His BMI is 31  making him clinically obese. He is a former smoker  having smoked for about 30 years before quitting about 5 years ago  and reports casual alcohol use. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 75.   The patient reports sudden onset chest pain started about 2 hours ago  which he describes as a pressure-like sensation located in the center of his chest. The pain radiates to his left upper extremity and neck. He also reports additional symptoms  including profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and feeling lightheaded. He denies recent illness  fever or trauma.  On presentation  the patient appears pale and is in visible discomfort. Physical examination reveals mildly elevated blood pressure (165/90 mmHg) and tachycardia (Heart Rate 105 bpm). His lung fields are clear and abdominal exam shows no abnormalities. BMI indicates obesity. Initial 12-lead EKG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggesting an inferolateral AMI. Troponin levels are pending.   The patient requires immediate management for AMI  including analgesia  antiplatelet therapy  and reperfusion strategy evaluation. His overall prognosis is guarded given his multiple coronary heart disease risk factors and late-presentation.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia.   Chief Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain that began an hour ago when he was at rest. The pain is centrally located  radiates to his left arm  and persistently lasts for more than 30 minutes. The pain is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He also reports shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and feeling light-headed.  History of Present Illness: No prior history of similar chest pain. Regular follow-up with primary care physician. Anti-hypertensive  cholesterol-lowering medications  and oral hypoglycemic agents prescribed as part of long-term management.    Social History: The patient has a 20-year pack history of smoking  does not consume alcohol  and denies illicit drug use. He is retired and lives with his wife.  Family History: His father suffered an acute myocardial infarction and died at age 68.  Examination: The patient is anxious  diaphoretic  and in obvious distress. Vital signs are BP: 160/90 mmHg  HR: 110 bpm  RR: 22 breaths per minute  O2 sat: 93% on room air  and Temp: 98F. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia; no murmurs noted. Pulmonary exam: lungs clear bilaterally.  Based on the patient’s presentation  the most likely working diagnosis is an acute myocardial infarction. This requires immediate confirmation via EKG and cardiac markers. The demographics  history  and findings presented here align frequently noted risk factors and features of acute myocardial infarction; the patient is of older age  male  African American ethnicity  has a history of significant risk factors including hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  smoking and hyperlipidemia  and has immediate family history of cardiac events.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 61-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had been a chronic smoker for 40 years but quit five years ago.  Presenting Problem: He presented to the emergency department with severe central chest pain  described as pressure-like and spreading to his left arm  which started an hour ago while he was gardening. He also reported associated shortness of breath  profuse sweating  nausea  and feelings of impending doom. No reported trauma  fever  cough or recent illnesses.   ED vitals and examination presented with a BP of 156/92 mmHg  Pulse 98 bpm  Oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac examination noted tachycardia  without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung examination was clear. However  the patient looked restless and diaphoretic.  Relevant Tests: EKG showed ST segment elevation in anterior leads  indicative of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.  The patient's demographics  medical history  and presentation of symptoms align with literature which states that myocardial infarctions are more common in males over 60 with risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and smoking history. The symptoms presented  such as left-sided chest pain  diaphoresis  and nausea  are consistent descriptions found in many cases of myocardial infarctions.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male named Robert  a retired construction worker who has been smoking for the past 40 years  a history of hypertension  and with a family history of coronary artery disease presents to the Emergency Room. He pinpoints the center of his chest  describing a sudden  severe  crushing type pain which started an hour ago while he is doing his morning jog. This pain radiates into his jaw and left arm and is associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and nausea. He has had episodes of chest discomfort in the past  typically after exertion  but these were relieved by rest. He denies any past surgical history or allergies  he is on metoprolol  and a daily aspirin for hypertension. Robert looks uncomfortable  diaphoretic with pallor  vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 24 per minute. His body mass index is in the overweight range. He has no pitting edema on the extremities  lung sounds are clear but the heart sound reveals a third heart sound. His ECG reveals ST segment elevations. His blood test results including troponin levels are pending.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents with severe  central chest pain that started around 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as persistent  crushing in nature  and radiating to his left arm. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and lightheadedness. The patient has a 40-pack-year history of smoking and a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease. He is non-compliant with his prescribed medications including aspirin  metformin  and atorvastatin. His physical examination reveals pallor  a cold sweat  tachycardia with a rate of 110 beats per minute  elevated blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  and bilateral basal lung crackles heard on chest auscultation. The rest of the physical examination was normal. His electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Mr. Smith is a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia who presents with acute onset of chest pain. His pain is severe and dull in nature  located in the middle of his chest and radiating towards his left arm  consistent for 45 minutes now. The pain started while he was doing yard work at home and didn't subdue with rest. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  and sweatiness. He denies any similar past episodes  or symptoms of fever  cough  or abdominal pain. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history and admits regular  moderate alcohol use. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. Mr. Smith is retired  lives with his wife  and their socioeconomic status is middle-class. There is a family history of early age coronary artery disease  his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. His initial vital signs show an elevated blood pressure and heart rate  his EKG suggests ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  prompting further evaluation for a possible ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Patient is a 63-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with severe chest pain. He suffers radiating pain on the left side of the chest that started approximately an hour ago  an intense  crushing pain associated with shortness of breath  sweating and nausea. He has no known allergies. He's a smoker with 30 pack-years of tobacco use history. He denies any illicit drug use. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 57. On examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic. Patient's blood pressure on presentation is 170/95 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. The ECG shows ST-segment elevation consistent with an acute myocardial infarction. The patient's blood glucose level is elevated. Immediate management and further diagnostic workup for acute myocardial infarction are initiated according to current guidelines.

Patient is a 66-year-old African-American male  retired factory worker  a current smoker with a history of hypertension  familial hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type II  presenting with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm that began approximately 2 hours prior. The pain is described as pressure-like  associated with diaphoresis  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness. There is no history of similar chest pain. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 58. His BP is 155/95 mmHg  pulse 105 beats/min  and BMI 29.6 kg/m2. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. Patient is currently sitting up on arrival  appears uncomfortable and anxious  repeatedly stating he feels 'not right'. This combination of chest pain  related symptoms  hypertension  and relevant family history in an African-American male of this age suggests a possible acute myocardial infarction.

Patient Information:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  with a body mass index (BMI) of 29 kg/m2.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw for the past two hours.   History of Present Illness:  The pain began while the patient was mowing his lawn and is associated with episodes of heavy sweating  nausea  and feeling of impending doom. The pain persists despite rest.  Past Medical History:  Positive for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication.   Review of Systems:  Other than the heart-related symptoms  patient denies any recent illnesses  infections  respiratory symptoms  changes in bowel or bladder function or weight changes.  Family History:  Father died at age 58 following a myocardial infarction.   Conditions:  Acute Myocardial Infarction  Symptoms:  Severe chest pain  pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  heavy sweating  nausea  feeling of impending doom.   Diagnostic Findings: Elevated cardiac biomarkers  ST Segment Elevation on ECG.   Summarization: This is a case of a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presenting with hallmark symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction: acute  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  severe perspiration  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom. His risk factors are his age  male gender  family history of premature coronary heart disease and his existing comorbidities. Key findings on cardiac evaluation will be the presence of ST-segment elevations on his EKG and raised cardiac biomarkers indicating myocardial injury.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson  a 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with abrupt onset of severe substernal chest pain radiating to the jaw and left arm for the past 2 hours. Associated symptoms include sweating  dyspnea  nausea  and lightheadedness. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack year smoking history. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. On physical exam  he appears pale and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse of 90 bpm  respirations 20 per minute  and O2 Saturation of 90% on room air. On auscultation  heart sounds are rhythmic with an S4 gallop and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The patient expresses a sense of impending doom. Laboratory workup revealed elevated troponin levels. The ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. These findings are consistent with an acute inferior wall ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI).

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history  presents with sudden onset severe chest pain of 2 hours duration  radiating to left arm  associated with diaphoresis and dyspnea. The pain is described as crushing in nature and was not relieved with rest. Physical examination reveals a pale  sweaty man in obvious distress with a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse 100 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min. Elevated troponin levels were noted in the initial lab workup. EKG findings were suspicious of an ST segment elevation in the anterior leads  indicative of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction.

A 61-year-old African American male  Mr. J  with a significant medical history of diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years  presented at the ER with symptoms of severe chest pain radiating to his left arm  along with sweating and shortness of breath. The symptoms started abruptly while he was doing gardening work at home one hour ago. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease with the patient's father having a myocardial infarction in his early sixties. On examination  he appears uncomfortable and pale  his blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  pulse is 110 bpm  irregular in rhythm  and respiratory rate is 22 per minute. His body mass index (BMI) is 30.2 indicating obesity.   Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  aVF  indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Blood works also show elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers  specifically  troponin and CK-MB.  The confluence of symptoms  risk factors  ECG  and blood indicators suggests a diagnosis of Acute Myocardial Infarction. Obesity and his pre-existing conditions  in addition to his smoking history  substantially increase his risk of coronary artery disease  potentially leading to the acute event.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a 15-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  a 20-pack-year smoking history  and a family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with symptoms consistent with acute myocardial infarction.  He arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw with accompanying symptoms of nausea  diaphoresis  dyspnea  and lightheadedness. The pain  graded at 9/10  started 3 hours prior to hospital presentation while he was at rest  and was not relieved by nitroglycerin or rest.   The patient's past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he was non-compliant with medications  and a brief episode of chest pain 6 months ago that resolved without medical intervention. His surgical history is unremarkable. He admits to 20 pack-year smoking history  moderate alcohol use and lack of regular physical activity.   His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and his older brother underwent angioplasty at 64 due to symptomatic CAD. His medications include aspirin and lisinopril  which he admits he has not been taking regularly. He has no known allergies. Overall  this clinical picture points towards a possible acute myocardial infarction  which requires immediate medical attention.

Patient: 62-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: History of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 which is poorly managed. He is a twenty-year pack smoker. Father died of myocardial infarction aged 65.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the ED with severe  crushing mid-sternal chest pain of two-hour duration. The pain radiates to his left arm and neck. He also reports experiencing an episode of extreme shortness of breath with sweating and light-headedness. On physical examination  the patient appears restless  diaphoretic and in distress.  Summary Problem Representation: 62-year-old hypertensive  diabetic  and smoker Caucasian male with a family history of myocardial infarction presenting with acute onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck  along with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and light-headedness indicative of acute myocardial infarction.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes and a 30-year history of cigarette smoking. He presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain  which he describes as ""crushing"" in nature  along with profuse sweating and radiation of pain to his left arm and jaw. The pain has been unremitting for the past two hours. He also reports experiencing episodes of mild chest discomfort over the past week. Furthermore  significant shortness of breath  nausea and feelings of impending doom accompany the pain. The patient’s risk factors elevate his likelihood of cardiovascular disease  including acute myocardial infarction due to the combination of long-term smoking with pre-existing conditions like diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His age  gender and race further increase his susceptibility to this condition based on epidemiological studies.

Patient: 60 years old Caucasian male  Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a smoker with 30 pack-year smoking history. His father died from a heart attack at age 62.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe  non-radiating chest pain that started about an hour ago  lasting more than 30 minutes  characterized as a heavy  crushing pain. The pain persists at rest  and is associated with sweating  shortness of breath  nausea and a feeling of impending doom. The patient rates his pain as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. Vital signs reveal elevated blood pressure (170/95 mmHg) and tachycardia (heart rate of 105 beats/min). Electrocardiogram findings are indicative of an ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).    Risk Factors: The patient's major risk factors for cardiovascular disease include male sex  advanced age  smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient's chief complaint  history of present illness  physical exam findings and EKG findings are consistent with an acute myocardial infarction.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm  which started an hour ago. He is also feeling sweaty and nauseated. He has been a chronic smoker for about 40 years and has a family history of coronary artery disease. His regular medications include metformin for his type 2 diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  but he admits to being non-compliant with them. On physical examination  the patient appears anxious and is diaphoretic. He has a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air.

Chief Complaint:   65-year-old Caucasian male presents with worsening chest pain characteristic of angina.  History of Present Illness:  The patient reports the onset of substernal chest pain  radiating to the left arm over the last 3 hours. He describes it as a heavy  squeezing discomfort. The pain is associated with dyspnea  diaphoresis and nausea. There has been no relief with rest. The patient also endorses associated symptoms of lightheadedness and fatigue.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and is a 45 pack-year smoker. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 7 years ago. He has had no prior coronary intervention or surgery but was previously diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease.  Family History:  The patient’s father had a myocardial infarction at age 55  and his mother had a stroke at age 60. His younger sister (age 62) was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Demographics:  The patient is a retired mechanic  living with his wife. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years  but denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He is from a lower socioeconomic background  has limited health literacy and a high-calorie diet.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appears distressed and anxious. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 105 bpm  respiratory rate 22/min  temp 98.6 °F  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air. Cardiac exam reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Pulmonary exam reveals clear breath sounds. No pedal pulses detected in both lower extremities.  Impression:  The patient’s demographic  clinical presentation and past medical history are highly suspicious of acute myocardial infarction. Immediate intervention (including EKG  labs  and potential coronary reperfusion) is crucial to minimize damage to the myocardium and improve prognosis.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired blue-collar worker with history of untreated hyperlipidemia  40-pack year smoking history  hypertension and a strongly positive family history of premature coronary artery disease.  Presentation: Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of central chest pain of 2 hours duration. Patient describes the pain as constant  heavy  radiating to the left arm and associated with cold sweats  and shortness of breath. Patient reports episode occurred when he was at rest and pain was not relieved by rest or have any factors that alleviated the pain.  Relevant History: Patient has been hypertensive from his forties  poorly controlled on antihypertensive drugs with average BP readings often being 150/95 mmHg. He has a history of hyperlipidemia but was non-complaint with statins. Patient also has 40-pack-year smoking history and has a positive family history of premature coronary artery disease with both his father and brother having died from heart attacks in their fifties. There is however no history of diabetes. Patient had a history of stable angina and was prescribed nitroglycerin but has misplaced his medication.  Given the patient's demographics  strong family history of cardiac disease  known treatment-resistant hypertension  hyperlipidemia  heavy smoking history  and symptoms of acute central chest pain that radiates to the left arm  it is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 30-pack-year smoking history  presents to the ED with severe crushing chest pain that started about 3 hours prior. The pain is located in the central chest region and radiates down his left arm. He describes it as ""like an elephant sitting on my chest "" and rates it as 8/10 in intensity. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath  excessive sweating  nausea  and a feeling of impending doom. His blood pressure on arrival is 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate is irregular at 102 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. He is diaphoretic and appears anxious. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4).

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker and retired factory worker  presents to the emergency room complaining of severe and sudden-onset chest pain  described as a crushing sensation  accompanied by shortness of breath and excessive sweating  which have developed over the past 2 hours. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports a regular use of antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemic agents. His family history is notable for a father who had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 69. The patient denies any alcohol or drug use  but admits he isn't maintaining a healthy diet and has a low physical activity level. His body mass index (BMI) is 30.7 kg/m2  indicating obesity. His vitals on presentation include a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The initial EKG shows significant ST-segment elevation in anterior leads  suggesting an anterior wall myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile:  - Demographics: John is a 59-year-old Caucasian male. - Residential status: He is a city dweller and lives with his wife. - Profession: He is a broker in a stressful financial firm.  Medical History:  - Risk Factors: John has hypertension  a history of smoking (recently quit 3 years ago)  and family history of coronary artery disease - his father had a heart attack at the age of 58. - Lifestyle: He has a somewhat sedentary lifestyle. He works at a desk for long hours  loves eating out  and struggles with managing a balanced diet  which contributes to his overweight status (BMI is 27.5).    - Other conditions: He has diabetes  which is managed with oral medications. He also has a history of high cholesterol  for which he takes statins.    Presenting Symptoms:   - Complaints: He presents to the emergency room complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw  that has been ongoing for the past 2 hours. He also reports shortness of breath  nausea  and cold sweats. - Vital: Blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate is 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute  temperature is 98.6°F  oxygen saturation level is 90% on room air.  Laboratory Findings:  - ECG findings indicate ST elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4). - Blood work showed significantly elevated Troponin-I levels with normal Complete Blood Count and serum electrolytes.   This representation mirrors the data found in many studies. Men have a higher occurrence of myocardial infarctions and the peak incidence occurs in the men aged about 55-64 years. Risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  family history of early heart disease  and diabetes significantly increase the risk of MI as per the American Heart Association.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 60 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired businessman BMI: 28.5 (overweight) Cigarette Smoker: Yes (30 pack year history) Alcohol: Social drinker  Medical History:  • Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago  on medication) • Diabetes mellitus type 2 (diagnosed 5 years ago  controlled with oral hypoglycemic) • Hyperlipidemia (diagnosed 8 years ago  on statins) • Family history of cardiovascular disease (Father died of myocardial infarction at age 60)  Presenting Chief Complaint:  • Sudden  severe chest pain radiating to left arm  • Shortness of breath • Cold sweats • Nausea • Light-headedness  Physical Examination:  Blood pressure: 165/95 mmHg (high) Heart rate: 110 bpm (high) Respiration rate: 22/min (high) Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air  Initial Diagnostic Tests:  ECG: ST segment elevation suggestive of myocardial infarction Cardiac Enzyme tests: Increased Troponin and CK-MB levels confirming myocardial damage  Based on demographic statistics  men over the age of 60 with a history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and family history of cardiovascular disease are at a high risk of heart diseases including acute myocardial infarction. The patient's presenting symptoms and elevation in cardiac biomarkers suggest an acute myocardial infarction  for which urgent medical attention and treatment are necessary.

Patient Representation:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating to left arm and jaw  short of breath  sweating.  Medical History: John has a history of Diabetes Mellitus type II which he manages with Metformin. He has Stage 2 Hypertension and is on a Calcium Channel Blocker (Amlodipine). He is also a 20-year smoker but quit 2 years ago. His father passed away at the age of 70 due to a heart attack and his mother has a history of stroke.  Physical Exam Findings: Blood pressure is high at 160/100 mmHg. Heart rate is elevated (tachycardia). ECG shows signs of ST-segment elevation.     Investigation Results: Blood tests show elevated Troponin levels.   Problem Representation: John Doe  a 65 year old caucasian male with known hypertension  diabetes  and a significant family history of cardiovascular disease  presents with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. The patient has a history of smoking for 20 years  which has now ceased for the past 2 years. His blood pressure is significantly elevated and heart rate is tachycardic. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation and his blood tests also reveal high troponin level  suggestive of acute myocardial infarction.    Reference: Smith JN  Negrelli JM  Manek MB  Hawes EM  Viera AJ. Diagnosis and management of acute coronary syndrome: an evidence-based update. J Am Board Fam Med. 2015 Mar-Apr;28(2):283-93. doi: 10.3122/jabfm.2015.02.140189. PMID: 25748770.

Problem Representation of Patient:   Demographic Information: - Age: The patient is a 66-year-old male  as the median age for a first heart attack is 65.6 years for males according to the American Heart Association. - Ethnicity: Caucasian  as myocardial infarction is generally more common in white men according to the CDC. - Occupation: Semi-retired businessman with a high stress job. - Lifestyle: The patient has a history of tobacco use and has minimal physical activity  both of which increase the risk of heart diseases.  - Diet: He has a high-fat diet and is overweight with a BMI of 30.  Presenting Symptoms:  - The patient typically presents with sudden onset chest pain  radiating to his left arm and jaw.  - The pain is severe  crushing in character  lasting more than 30 minutes and not relieved by rest. - Associated symptoms include: shortness of breath  sweating  nausea  and lightheadedness.  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension: He has a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension. - Diabetes Mellitus: Patient has Type II diabetes that is managed with oral hypoglycemic medication  - Hyperlipidemia: The patient has been diagnosed with high LDL cholesterol and low HDL cholesterol levels. - Family History: There is a family history of ischemic heart disease  his father and brother experienced heart attacks in their early 60s.  Physical Findings and Diagnostic Studies: - Physical exam reveals an anxious man in distress  with elevated blood pressure  increased heart rate. - Electrocardiogram (ECG) showing ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V4  suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. - Blood investigations confirmed the diagnosis with a raised Troponin I level which is a cardiac marker specific for myocardial necrosis. - His lipid profile shows elevated LDL and low HDL levels  with an elevated HbA1c suggestive of poor glycemic control  further increasing his risk for coronary artery disease.  This patient presentation is a typical case of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction  belonging to the demographic group that is at the highest risk.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Joe  who is a retired construction worker from suburban Chicago. He is a devoted husband  a father of two daughters  and a grandfather of three grandchildren. Joe is a former smoker who quit smoking ten years ago after a 35-year habit of a pack of cigarettes per day. He is a social drinker who indulges during family gatherings and special occasions. Joe's diet is not particularly healthy  often favoring red meat  fried food  and sweets. He hasn't been physically active since retirement due to an arthritic knee. His BMI falls within the obese range.  Past Medical History: Joe has a complex medical history  including well-controlled hypertension on Lisinopril  medically managed type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and osteoarthritis. Joe's father died of heart attack at the age of 59  and his mother had stroke when she was 72. He had a colonoscopy eight years ago due to occasional rectal bleeding which revealed diverticulosis.  Presenting Problem: Joe arrives at the ER complaining of acute onset of severe chest pain  which he described as a 'heavy' pressure that radiates to his left arm and jaw. He also mentioned he's been feeling generally unwell  fatigued  and has shortness of breath for the past week. EKG suggests ST-segment elevation  indicating a probable myocardial infarction.  This case reflects a typical patient profile of myocardial infarction  taking into account the common age group  gender  lifestyle factors  and comorbidities associated with this condition as found in literature.

Problem Representation:  Patient Characterization:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden-onset  severe  crushing chest pain  described as being “heavy” in nature and radiating to his left arm and jaw. The patient reports associated symptoms  including shortness of breath  nausea  feeling of impending doom  and profuse sweating. The patient's pain has been persistent for the past 90 minutes and is not relieved by rest.   Demographics:  The patient’s BMI is 32  indicating obesity  and he has been a heavy smoker (2 packs per day) for the past 40 years. The patient is retired  lives with his wife  and is not physically active on a regular basis. He admits to moderate alcohol use and has a diet high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables.   Relevant Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history notable for uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin. Upon checking old records  his latest fasting blood glucose level was 152 mg/dL and blood pressure consistently above 140/90 mmHg. There is also family history of premature coronary artery disease  with his father dying of a myocardial infarction at 60 and his brother having percutaneous coronary intervention at 58. There are no known drug allergies.  Note: This problem representation is designed to present a typical case for a high-risk demographic group with an acute myocardial infarction. However  acute myocardial infarction can present in any demographic  so it is critical to maintain a high index of suspicion in all patient populations.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - Gender: Male - Age: 65 years old - Race/Ethnicity: White - Occupation: Retired office worker - Marital Status: Married - Previous Residence: Urban area  Presenting Problem:   - Complain of acute  severe chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw  lasting for more than 30 minutes. - Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and sweating.  Past Medical History:  - History of hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  managed through medication.  - Smoker for 40 years  approximately 20 cigarettes per day. - Known type 2 diabetics for the past 10 years  managed with oral antidiabetics. - Had an episode of angina pectoris two years ago. - Family history includes a father who had suffered a myocardial infarction at age 57.  Diet & Lifestyle:  - Regular alcohol intake: Approximately two bottles of beer per day. - Sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. - Diet predominantly high in saturated fats and sugars with low fruits and vegetable intake.  Medications:   - Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension  - Metformin 500mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes  Allergies:  - No known drug allergies.  Recent Changes:  - Patient has been experiencing increased stress due to recent financial difficulties.  Summary: This is a case representation of a 65-year-old white male from an urban area with a significant history of smoking  known type 2 diabetes  and hypertension. The patient's family history  lifestyle  stress and dietary habits add to the risk of acute myocardial infarction.
