Blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats/per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths/per minute  and body temperature 37.1oC. Cardiovascular examination reveals normal heart sounds with no audible murmurs. Lung examination is unremarkable.  Summary: This case portrays a common demographic group at high risk for Acute Myocardial Infarction  Hispanic males in their 60s with a history of smoking  diabetes  and hypertension. The student's task here is to recognize the significance of the patient's symptoms (typical chest pain with an episode of shortness of breath and sweating) in the context of his demographic data and past medical history  leading to a prioritized differential diagnosis list  immediate investigations  and treatment plan. The case study provides a basis for further discussion about the importance of risk stratification and preventive care for Acute Myocardial Infarction.

Patient Demographic:  Gender: Male Age: 60  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Accountant Living Situation: Living with spouse   Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for 10 years  being controlled by Lisinopril 2. Hyperlipidemia for 8 years  taking Atorvastatin 3. Type 2 diabetes for 5 years  being managed with Metformin 4. Smoker  having a smoking history of 30 ""pack-years"" 5. Father died from a heart attack at age 62   Presenting Complaints:  The patient arrives at the emergency department with complaints of intense chest pain that started about an hour ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is central and radiating to his left arm. He also describes the pain as a feeling of pressure  similar to having a heavy weight on his chest. He rates the pain as 8 on a scale of 1-10. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  sudden onset of sweat  and a sense of impending doom. He tried resting but the pain did not subside.   Note: The case was designed taking into account the demographic most at risk for myocardial infarction - middle-aged to older men  Caucasians  with risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and a family history of heart disease. Also  the symptoms presented are in line with typical complaints in acute myocardial infarction  particularly the angiographic ""left arm"" pain and other symptoms such as dyspnea  sweating  and anxiety.   Further investigations and management can be tailored based on this case to educate medical students on handling acute myocardial infarction.

Case Report - Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: Name: Mr. X Age: 65 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Engineer Living Status: Lives alone    Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years  which has been irregularly managed. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but smoked for 30 years prior. He has Type II diabetes diagnosed 8 years ago. He is also a chronic alcoholic. Family history includes his late father  who suffered a heart attack when he was 60  and his mother has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Key Complaints acknowledged during the consultation:  Mr. X walked into the ER with complaints of severe chest pain described as pressing  tight in nature  located mid-sternum and radiating to the left arm. The pain started while he was resting at home  initially mild but increased progressively over 30 minutes and is not getting relieved with rest. He also has nausea  shortness of breath  diaphoresis  lightheadedness  fatigue  and palpitations.  From the literature  it is known that Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) is more common in males than in females  and it occurs more often in those over 50 years of age. Also  AMI is seen commonly in patients with hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  smoking history  alcohol abuse  and family history of cardiovascular disease  which matches the profile of our patient. African Americans also have an elevated risk of AMI due to a higher prevalence of secondary risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes among them.  This concise clinical scenario allows us to explore the signs  symptoms  and risk factors for Acute Myocardial Infarction while providing insights into a culturally appropriate context considering the elevated risk in the African American male population. It would help medical students to understand patient complaints  co-relate their theoretical knowledge with clinical presentations  and manage the medical condition most effectively considering the best interest of the patient.

Patient demographics:   The patient is a 62-year-old Hispanic male named Roberto Alvarez  who works as a mechanic. Roberto is married and lives with his wife and their dog  and has two grown-up children. He is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol moderately  and have no known drug allergies. He lives in an urban area of Los Angeles.  Past medical history:  Roberto had been diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  for which he is on medications including metformin and a beta-blocker. He has a history of Hypercholesterolemia but is inconsistent with his statin prescription and dietary recommendations. Both his father and grandfather had premature coronary artery disease  with his father dying from a massive myocardial infarction at 55.  Complaint:  Roberto presented to the emergency room with severe chest pain  which he described as ‘a heavy pressure on his chest’  that started while he was lifting heavy equipment at work. The pain radiated to his left arm and was associated with profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom. He also reported episodes of similar but less severe pain over the past week  which typically occurred with exertion and relieved with rest. Roberto never experienced this kind of a pain before which usually subsides after a brief rest.  Roberto Alvarez represents an accurate demographic representation as literature suggests that men especially those with a family history of coronary artery disease are at a higher risk for acute myocardial infarction. Furthermore  Hispanics have been shown to have a higher prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors including diabetes mellitus and hypertension  potentially leading to poorer cardiovascular outcomes. Roberto’s lifestyle and negligent attitude towards diet and medication compliance represent another realistic factor often found in such patients.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He is retired  lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. Mr. Smith is moderately active and is a non-smoker. He occasionally drinks alcohol during social events. He is currently covered by Medicare.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a long-standing history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions have been relatively well-controlled with medications involving ACE-inhibitors for the hypertension and Metformin for the diabetes. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. However  Mr. Smith hypercholesterolemia has been diagnosed but non-compliant with his statins therapy.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith walked into the Emergency Department at 10 AM in the morning complaining of severe  crushing chest pain which started an hour ago. The pain is located in the center of his chest and radiates to his left arm and jaw. He is also experiencing episodic shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. No associated symptoms of fever  cough  or palpitations. He denies any recent trauma or injury. The pain occurred at rest and had not been relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin.   This case represents a common presentation of acute myocardial infarction  typically seen in older adults with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Remember to prioritize immediate cardiovascular assessment and management in such presentations.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Presentation: Mr. Gonzalez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department at 3 a.m complaining of severe  crushing chest pain  which he describes as a ""heavy weight"" in the center of his chest. The pain began 6 hours prior and has been continuous since. The pain radiates to his left arm and up to his lower jaw. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  profuse sweating  and lightheadedness.   Patient Demographics: Mr. Gonzalez is a retired teacher  married with 3 adult children and 6 grandchildren. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He is fluent in both English and Spanish.   Past Medical History: - Hypertension for the past ten years controlled with medication (Losartan 50mg daily) - Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years ago and is diet-controlled - Dyslipidemia managed with simvastatin - No known allergies  Family history is notable for a father who died of a heart attack at age 72 and a brother diagnosed with angina pectoris. Mr. Gonzalez's mother has Type 2 diabetes and his eldest sister suffers from Hypertension.  Key Complaints: - Severe  continuous  chest pain - Pain radiates to the left arm and jaw - Shortness of breath - Nausea - Profuse sweating - Lightheadedness  Remarks: This case was designed considering the prevalence of myocardial infarction among older adults  especially those with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia. The choice for a Hispanic patient attempts to reflect the diversity of patients you could encounter. The symptoms offered reflect the signs of possible ongoing cardiac ischemia. This case should highlight the importance of rapid assessment and initiation of treatment in acute myocardial infarction to prevent further myocardial damage and improve survival odds.

Case Report for Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics  Name: Patient X Age: 65 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired construction worker  Past Medical History  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago  on Antihypertensive medications. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with metformin. 3. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 3 years ago  managed with statins. 4. Smoking: Heavy smoker  1 pack/day for the last 35 years.   Key Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with: 1. Severe chest pain: Described as a squeezing sensation located in the center of his chest  radiating down to his left arm. The onset was sudden  noted while shoveling snow  and has persisted for the past two hours. 2. Shortness of Breath: Noticed along with the chest pain  worsened on exertion and slightly relieved by rest. 3. Profuse Sweating: Accompanied by a feeling of nausea  and lightheadedness.   Note to the Educator:  This case is designed to train medical students about acute myocardial infarction (MI)  with a focus on identification  immediate management  and the importance of a thorough medical history. The patient's demographic profile and medical history were devised based on the literature  which highlights that Acute MI often occurs in men over 60  with African Americans having a higher risk than Caucasians. Other representative risk factors included in this scenario are hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. These should direct students towards a high suspicion of Acute MI when presenting with the classic symptoms of chest pain  dyspnea  and diaphoresis.  The medical students should also learn to rule out differential diagnoses such as angina  pericarditis or aortic dissection  but given the patient’s risk factors and the character of his pain  acute myocardial infarction should be the most likely diagnosis. They should understand the importance of quickly initiating therapy aimed to restore the coronary blood flow while managing the patient’s discomfort and preventing further myocardial injury.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Background:   Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 65 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant  Past medical history:   Mr. Smith has been dealing with hypertension for the past 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 5 years. He has been prescribed records of medication for both conditions. Despite medical advice  he continues a sedentary lifestyle with poor dietary habits. The patient has a history of smoking one pack a day for the past 40 years  though he claims to have quit two years ago.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith arrived at the hospital complaining of severe  crushing chest pain that began while he was mowing the lawn approximately 2 hours ago. He described the pain as a heavy pressure that radiated to his left arm and jaw. He also reported experiencing sudden shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. Sitting down and rest did not relieve symptoms  prompting his visit to the emergency department.  Note: This case is typical for a Myocardial Infarction and reflects epidemiological data from the literature. Heart disease  including MI  tends to be more common in men  especially those over the age of 45  and those who smoke  have diabetes  hypertension  or a sedentary lifestyle. Likewise  the classic symptoms of chest pain  dyspnea  and patients feeling an impending doom are commonly reported.

Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 64-year-old African American male  named ""Mr. Smith"". He has a known history of diabetes type 2  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and reports alcohol use in moderation. There is a family history of ischemic heart disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Mr. Smith is a retired mechanic and is married with two children.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Smith arrived at the ER with complaints of severe chest pain  which he described as 'crushing' in character  radiating to the left arm and jaw. He also reported symptoms of shortness of breath  sweating and feeling nauseous. The symptoms started while he was at rest  watching television  approximately 2 hours prior to his visit to the hospital.  Past Medical History: - Diabetes Type 2: Diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with metformin. - Hypertension: Diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled with lisinopril. - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  controlled with statin therapy.  Current Medications: - Metformin 500mg twice daily - Lisinopril 10mg once daily - Statin (Atorvastatin) 20mg once daily  Family History:  - Father: Died of myocardial infarction at age 70 - Mother: Alive  has type 2 diabetes and hypertension - Brother: Alive  has hyperlipidemia - Children: Healthy  Social History:  - Former smoker (quit 10 years ago) - Drinks alcohol socially  denies illicit drug usage - Retired mechanic  currently leading a relatively sedentary life  Physical Exam: - Blood Pressure: 155/95mmHg - Heart Rate: 105 beats per minute - Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per minute - Oxygen Saturation: 92% on room air  - Noted to be diaphoretic and anxious  Relevant findings on examination: - Cardiovascular exam shows an increased heart rate  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops noted. - Lung exam is clear with no rales or wheezes. - Abdomen is soft  non-tender  no organomegaly.  - Extremities show no edema  pulses are intact.  Discussion Points: - The importance of early recognition of acute myocardial infarction based on patient history and presenting signs and symptoms. - The role of immediate diagnostic tests  such as ECG and cardiac enzyme studies. - Initial management steps upon suspecting AMI. - Risk factors for AMI and the role of preventative measures.

Case Study: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: Patient Name: Mr. Jones Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Marital status: Married Insurance status: Medicare  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a significant past medical history with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both diagnosed 8 years ago and managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. He is also a former smoker  with a 30 pack-year history  although he quit smoking ten years ago. His father had a heart attack at the age of 68.  Patient's Key Complaints: Mr. Jones presents to the emergency room complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw starting about an hour ago. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure  rating it at an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10. He also mentions that he is feeling diaphoretic  nauseous  and short of breath. His wife becomes concerned and called an ambulance when he began looking pale and clammy. The symptoms occurred at rest after dinner and have persisted.  Issues of Note: Given Mr. Jones' age  sex  past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and significant smoking history  he falls into the high-risk group for coronary artery disease  putting him at an elevated risk for acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Caucasian men tend to have higher rates of AMI compared to other races and women. His symptomatology – chest pain  radiating pain  diaphoresis  nausea  and shortness of breath – are characteristic of AMI.  Objective for Medical Students: a) Identify the clinical symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction. b) Appropriately identify risk factors based on patient history. c) Understand the importance of rapid diagnosis and treatment to minimize damage to myocardium. d) Familiarize themselves with typical tests for diagnosing AMI  such as electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac enzyme tests.  e) Learn about the possible treatment options for an AMI  including medications and other interventional activities such as stenting or a coronary artery bypass graft.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Goodson Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint: Mr. Goodson presents with acute  severe chest pain radiating to his left arm that started approximately 3 hours prior to his visit. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis (extensive sweating)  and feelings of intense fear/anxiety.  Past Medical History: Mr. Goodson has a past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  for which he takes Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He has also reported a smoking history of 30 pack years and moderate alcohol consumption. Family history is positive for coronary artery disease with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Clinical Examination: On examination  Mr. Goodson appears in distress  sweating profusely. His blood pressure is high at 160/100 mmHg and heart rate is irregular at 110 bpm. From the physical exam  he shows symptoms of respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.  Preliminary Analysis: Based on patient demographics  past medical history  and emergency presentation  the working diagnosis is Acute Myocardial Infarction(AMI). The geriatric male patient falls within the commonly affected age group  and the risk factors - hypertension  diabetes  smoking - fall in line with noted risk factors for AMI  as mentioned in various medical literature. The presented symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis further support this leading diagnosis.  Next Steps for Student: The trainee/student will be advised to demonstrate proper handling of such an emergency by acting quickly to confirm the diagnosis and manage the patient. The student should suggest relevant diagnostic tests  like ECG and cardiac biomarker tests to confirm AMI  and understand the importance of immediate pharmacological management strategies  such as MONA (Morphine  Oxygen  Nitrates  and Aspirin). The overall goal is to stabilize the patient  minimize heart damage  and prevent life-threatening complications.  This case design represents a common presentation of AMI  highlighting key risk factors  symptoms  and demographics  allowing for a comprehensive and impactful learning experience.

Patient Information: Mrs. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic woman with a BMI of 30.0  presents to the emergency department. She reports her occupation as a housewife and lives in an urban setting with her husband.  Past Medical History: She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  managed with metformin and lisinopril respectively. She quit smoking 5 years ago  but smoked for around 30 years before that. She consumes alcohol occasionally and follows a diet which is high in salt and fats. She has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with her father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Chief Complaints: Mrs. Rodriguez reports an abrupt onset of severe chest pain  which she describes as a heaviness in her chest. She indicates that the pain radiates to her left arm and jaw. She also reports shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  and feeling faint. These symptoms started around an hour before she came to the hospital.  Remarks:  Consider the statistics of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) that indicate higher rates in older adults  men  and individuals with certain risk factors (such as diabetes  smoking  and hypertension). Be that as it may  it is also important to note that women  especially older women  and people from different racial/ethnic groups also experience AMI. Hence  Mrs. Rodriguez's case is constructed to reflect a patient population that might be statistically lesser but is very much existent in real-world settings.  The case sets a base for teaching recognition of risk factors in AMI  highlighting symptoms of AMI in women  and incorporating the socioeconomic elements that play into the healthcare disparities. A thorough history and a focused physical exam  followed by the appropriate use of diagnostic tests are the cornerstones of early recognition and management of AMI. Therefore  the case also emphasizes presenting complaints typical of an AMI.   Please adjust patient presentation  progression  and test results to fit your educational activity's specific aim.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 62-year-old African American male  who is a retired electrician from Dallas  Texas. He is married and resides with his wife and two adult children. The patient is a veteran and has access to decent health care. He doesn't smoke  having quit 15 years prior  and drinks moderately. His BMI is 29 and he has recently started to exercise due to concerns over health.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years and hyperlipidemia for the past 5 years. Both conditions are managed with medication (lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia). There is a family history of coronary artery disease: his father had a heart attack in his mid-60s.   Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain of sudden onset radiating to his left arm and up his jaw. He describes it as a heavy  tight sensation  which started while he was mowing the lawn approximately 2 hours prior to presentation. Along with chest pain  the patient reported feeling nauseated  shortness of breath  and breaking out in a cold sweat. He does not have any complaint of loss of consciousness  palpitations  or pain elsewhere.   The targeted demographic of a 62-year-old African American man is due to the high incidence of heart disease in this population. Literature has shown that African American men have a higher rate of heart disease compared to other races and that the first presentation of heart disease is often a myocardial infarction. The occupational background underscores a previous work-related physical activity  which has not translated into his retired life  therefore representing a significant risk. His age also puts him at high risk  as the majority of people who die of coronary heart disease are 65 or older.

Patient Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant and non-smoker. He is a resident of a suburban area. Weight: 86 kg  Height: 1.75 m. He is married with 2 adult children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of high cholesterol and hypertension for which he was previously advised lifestyle modifications and was prescribed statins and ACE inhibitors. He has no documented history of diabetes  kidney disease  or any malignant diseases. There are no known substance abuse issues. His father had his first myocardial infarction at 60 years.  Key/Chief Complaints: The patient was brought to the emergency department (ED) by his wife. He had been experiencing central chest pain  described as a pressure-like sensation  for six hours prior to arrival at the hospital. The pain radiated to his left limb and was associated with diaphoresis and nausea.   The patient also reported a recent pattern of angina on exertion that improved with rest  but he dismissed it as indigestion considering his diet and did not seek any medical aid before. He was on his regular medication and denied any recent changes in his medication.  Note:  The case provided is modeled on common presentation patterns for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI). AMI  while non-exclusive to any particular demographic  is most frequently seen in men over 65  and tends to present more often in those with a familial history of heart disease. The chosen patient background and clinical presentation is consistent with literature  but it is important to remember that AMI can present in diverse populations with variable signs and symptoms.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. James Allen Age: 60 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Medical History: Mr. Allen has a documented history of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM)  the treatment of which involves dietary control and oral hypoglycemic agents. He has a 20-year history of smoking but stopped 5 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol socially and has a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father had passed away from a heart attack at age 65.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Allen presented to the emergency department with acute  severe  central chest pain radiating to the left arm and lower jaw. He also reported experiencing an episode of sweatiness and light-headedness. The symptoms have started while he was carrying grocery bags up stairs to his apartment and hadn’t adequately released even after sitting down for over 30 minutes. He also mentioned experiencing episodes of angina on exertion for the last two months  which were relieved by rest.  Further Investigation and Diagnosis:  Based on these symptoms  and his risk factors like age  male sex  history of hypertension  DM  smoking  and strong family history  an acute myocardial infarction is suspected. Immediate EKG  troponin levels  and other necessary lab tests are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and guide further treatment.  This case is designed to represent majority of the acute myocardial infarction (AMI) cases  in which patients often present late with these typical complaints. It also highlights the high risk factors associated with AMI - age  male gender  hypertension  diabetes  former smoker  sedentary lifestyle and genetic predisposition. Being aware of these factors in patients presenting with similar symptoms should prompt immediate action. This profile is representative of the typical AMI patient population as described in many epidemiological studies.

Patient Profile:  Sex: Male  Age: 60  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Sales executive  Location: Mississippi  USA  Marital Status: Married   Past Medical History: Our patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been a smoker for the past 35 years with a pack/day frequency. He is currently being treated with Metformin for his diabetes  attends regular doctor visits for his high blood pressure  and takes statins for his high cholesterol.  Presenting Complaints: The patient had been experiencing episodes of chest pain over a period of a few days. The pain was described as a crushing sensation  located centrally and radiating to the left shoulder and lower jaw. These episodes were occurring with increasing frequency and intensity. The patient also reported shortness of breath  profoundly during the episodes of chest pain  and general fatigue. In addition  the patient mentioned feeling lightheadedness and excessive sweating during these episodes.  In the literature  acute myocardial infarction is more common in males and older adults. Modifiable risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and smoking are also significant contributors to the development of myocardial infarction. This patient's case aligns with these demographic trends and risk factors. The presenting symptoms are also classic for myocardial infarction and should trigger further cardiac evaluation. As an educator  you can build upon this case by discussing differential diagnoses  appropriate investigations  and management plans for a potential acute myocardial infarction.   The goal of this education module would be to familiarize students with presentation patterns for diverse patient populations  understand how to recognize and diagnose acute myocardial infarction  and identify risk factors and how to manage them in order to improve patient outcomes.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban area. His socioeconomic status is middle class and he is retied from his job as a school teacher. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years but currently quit two months ago. He is overweight (BMI 27)  and his diet is high in saturated fats and sodium.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension that was diagnosed 8 years ago and is currently on Lisinopril 10mg daily. He also has type 2 diabetes  diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with Metformin.  He has a familial history of ischemic heart disease  with his father having a heart attack at the age of 60.   Presenting Complaints: The patient came to the emergency department complaining of a sudden  severe chest pain that he described as crushing  located in the center of the chest  and radiating to the left arm and neck. The pain started in the morning while he was resting and it persisted for about two hours. He rated it as a 10  on a 0-10 severity scale. Other associated symptoms included profuse cold sweats  nausea  dizziness  and shortness of breath  especially upon exertion. He mentioned also that he has been experiencing intermittent chest discomfort and excessive fatigue during the last month  but he assumed it to be a result of stress.  Note: This case design gives an accurate representation of the demographics most typically having an Acute Myocardial Infarction  based on numerous epidemiological studies found in the literature. Middle-aged to elderly Caucasian males  especially those with risk factors like smoking  hypertension  diabetes and familial history have a high predisposition to heart diseases.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. James Brown Age: 66  Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Truck Driver Location: Urban  Midwestern United States  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus 8 years ago. Despite being a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  he had smoked for approximately 30 years beforehand  averaging a pack per day. Mr. Brown's family history is also significant  with his father having experienced a heart attack at the age of 68. In terms of medication  Mr. Brown takes metformin for his diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  although he admits to not always taking them regularly due to cost issues.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Brown presented to the emergency room with approximately 2 hours of ongoing central chest pain  which he described as ""pressure-like"" and ""radiating to his left arm"". He also experienced associated shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. These symptoms were unprovoked and occurred while he was watching television at home.  Clinical Examination: Upon examination  Mr. Brown appeared sweaty and was visibly distressed. He was obese with a body mass index of 32 kg/m2. Vital signs on admission were as follows: blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  pulse 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and room air oxygen saturation 94%. Cardiac examination revealed no abnormalities  lung fields were clear  and no peripheral edema was observed.  Lab Results: Electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in the inferolateral leads  indicative of an acute myocardial infarction. Serum troponin levels were elevated. Further biochemistry showed poor glycemic control and elevated cholesterol.  This case is designed to reflect the demographic group most affected by acute myocardial infarction in the United States  i.e.  older  African American men with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. The case encourages students to consider the importance of social determinants of health  such as medication adherence and healthcare accessibility  in the management of chronic illnesses.    This clinical case can be used for teaching medical students about recognizing and managing acute myocardial infarction  including the crucial role of urgent revascularization strategies. It provides opportunities for a rich discussion on preventive strategies and the management of risk factors for coronary artery disease.

Case Name: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Diabetic Female Patient  Demographics:  Patient is a 65-year-old African-American female  retired school teacher  who lives with her husband. She is obese with a BMI of 35; a non-smoker; and drinks alcohol occasionally. She is from a low socio-economic background.  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past ten years and has been on oral hypoglycemic drugs (Metformin). Hypertension was diagnosed at the same time  for which she is maintained on Lisinopril. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease with her father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 59. There is no diagnosed mental health condition  and no history of hospitalizations.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought into the Emergency Department by her husband  who reports that she was complaining of sudden-onset severe  crushing chest pain that started about 2 hours ago and is radiating to the left arm and jaw. She's also complaining of shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. She had mild intermittent chest pain over the last week that she dismissed as heartburn  and she thought her increased fatigue over the same period was due to older age and increased stress.  Note: The chosen demographics and relevant comorbidities reflect the literature's demographic data  indicating an increased prevalence of Acute Myocardial Infarction in older individuals  specifically in the African-American population  in people with a history of diabetes  hypertension  and individuals with obesity. Women  especially of post-menopausal age  may experience atypical symptoms of myocardial ischemia  such as fatigue and nausea. The dismissal of indicative symptoms as trivial  as shown by this patient  is likewise a common trend documented in literature. The socio-economic context may also be significant  as low income has been linked with heightened risk of myocardial infarction and poorer outcomes.

Case Study: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information:  - Name: Joseph Bennett - Age: 67 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired school principal - Marital status: Married  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Bennett came to the emergency department complaining of severe  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm that started about two hours ago. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath  sweating  and a sense of impending doom.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Bennett was diagnosed with hypertension twelve years ago  for which he takes a daily antihypertensive medication. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  managed with lifestyle modification and metformin. He's a former smoker (quit 10 years ago)  but has a 30 pack-year history. His father passed away at the age of 60 due to a sudden heart attack. There is no other significant family or occupational history. Mr. Bennett also admits to consumption of a diet rich in saturated fats and leading a somewhat sedentary lifestyle.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  he appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs showed tachycardia (heart rate 101 bpm)  hypertension (blood pressure 160/95 mmHg)  respirations 22 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The cardiac exam revealed no murmurs or gallops  but the patient was found to have cold extremities. Lungs sounded clear on auscultation.  The above case is a classic presentation of acute myocardial infarction. It takes into account the fact  as seen in research and literature  that men  particularly white (Caucasian)  aged 65 and older  with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and smoking are at a higher risk for Acute Myocardial Infarction.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information:  - Name: William Johnson - Age: 57 years old - Sex: Male - Weight: 225 lbs. - Height: 5'9"" - Occupation: Computer Analyst - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle  occasional smoker with heavy alcohol consumption on weekends  and irregular exercise regimen. - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian - Family history: Father died of heart attack at age 62  older brother has heart disease.  Presenting Complaints & Clinical History:  Mr. Johnson presents with sudden  severe  continuous chest pain over the last 90 minutes. The pain is mid-sternal  radiating to the left shoulder and down his left arm. Patient also feels lightheaded with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea.  Relevant Past Medical History:  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 5 years ago - Hypertension - Diagnosed 7 years ago - High cholesterol - Diagnosed 6 years ago - Mild obesity - BMI noted regularly at or above 30 - No history of heart disease or heart-related hospitalizations - Non-compliant with prescribed medications for control of diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol   Long-term Conditions:  - Poorly controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Chronic hypertension - Hyperlipidemia  - Mild obesity - Chronic alcohol misuse  This case report is designed with a focus on a statistically significant demographic i.e.  males over 50 years old with race Caucasian (White) have a higher preponderance of Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI). The implemented clinical history and complaints are also consistent with common precursors to AMI. The presentation of sudden  severe chest pain  nausea  and diaphoresis is characteristic of myocardial infarction. These factors will provide medical students with valuable insights and knowledge  enabling them to improve their diagnoses and treatment planning skills.

Case Study: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Profile:  Name: John Raymond Age: 58 years Gender: Male Race: African American Occupation: High school teacher Location: Urban residential area in Midwest  United States  Past Medical History: John Raymond is an African American male with a history of controlled hypertension (blood pressure 130/85 on medication) and hyperlipidemia (medicated with simvastatin). He has smoked a packet of cigarettes per day for the past seventeen years. His father died of a myocardial infarction in his early sixties.  Presenting Complaints: John came to the emergency department (ED) because he developed sudden severe chest pain over the sternum that radiated to his left arm. The pain started while he was teaching at school with an intensity he describes as ""9 out of 10"". He also reports accompanying sweating and mild shortness of breath. He felt nauseous and fatigued but did not vomit. John denied any history of similar chest pain  palpitations  syncope  cough  or recent fever.  Note:  Statistical data shows that African Americans  especially males  are at a comparatively higher risk for acute myocardial infarction. A combination of factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking further increases this risk. This designed case provides medical students the opportunity to learn the presentation  risk factors  and management of acute myocardial infarction in a real-life scenario considering demographic representation.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male who works as a cab driver visited a local emergency department.  Chief Complaints: He reports experiencing severe chest pain over the past 2 hours  which he describes as ""Heavy pressure-like sensation"". He also mentions associated symptoms of nausea  sweating  and shortness of breath. The pain does not abate with rest and is not related to exertion.  Past Medical History: He is a known case of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years but has inconsistent medical follow-ups and medication control due to financial constraints. He used to smoke one pack of cigarettes/day for the last 35 years. He admits a high-fat diet intake with low fruit and vegetable consumption  as well as a sedentary lifestyle associated with his job. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 60.   History of Present Illness: The patient noticed initial symptoms of uneasiness and discomfort in the chest about two weeks ago after vigorous physical exertion. He disregarded these symptoms associating it with his daily physical exhaustion from work. However  the symptoms have intensified in the past few hours  forcing him to seek medical attention.  Based on a study by the American Heart Association  African American males carry a high risk for myocardial infarction  especially if they have a history of hypertension  smoking  poor dietary habits  diabetes  and a lack of regular exercise.  Additional demographic information:  He lives with his wife and two adult children. He mentioned that he has been stressed about financial instability in the family in recent times.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Alvarez is a 62-year-old Hispanic male; a retired construction worker who resides in a semi-urban neighborhood with his wife.  Past Medical History:  He has a diagnosis of hypertension for the last 10 years  well managed with medication (Lisinopril). He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 55  and his older brother had a non-fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Mr. Alvarez's cholesterol levels have been slightly elevated in the last few clinical reviews. He does not have diabetes or any other known health issues. His BMI falls within the overweight range.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Alvarez came to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain that started about three hours ago. The pain is described as tightness  radiating to the left arm and up to the jaw  accompanied by shortness of breath and cold sweats. The symptoms started while he was gardening at home. Nitro-glycerine  taken as per his brother's suggestion  did not alleviate the pain. He denies any associated nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness but reports feeling light-headed and scared of passing out. Over the past week  he did notice increased fatigue and occasional episodes of indigestion  which he dismissed as symptoms of stress and overwork.  (As per current medical literature  this case has been chosen to represent one of the high-risk ethnic groups for cardiovascular disease  with a background history of hypertension  and a family history of heart disease. Considering the real-world prevalence rates  the ethnic  age  and risk factor representation is quite precise. This case would help the medical students understand the clinical features of acute myocardial infarction  the role of family history  and the therapeutic implications.)

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: Mr. J.P. is a 62-year-old African American male  living in an urban environment in the Midwest United States. He is a retired factory worker and lives with his wife in an apartment. He is moderately active and has been smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years.  Past Medical History: Mr. J.P. has a past medical history of hypertension which has been managed effectively with lisinopril 10 mg daily over the past 10 years. He also has a slightly elevated LDL cholesterol of 140 mg/dL.  Over the years  despite encouragement from healthcare providers  Mr. J.P. has struggled to quit smoking. He reports having a BMI of 28  indicative of overweight. His diet includes a high intake of processed and fast foods. There is a notable family history of cardiovascular disease; his father underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery at the age of 55.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. J.P. presents to the emergency department with a history of sudden onset chest pain which started approximately 3 hours ago while watching TV at home. He describes this pain as a heaviness in his chest  which radiates to his left arm. He also reports associated symptoms including shortness of breath  sweating  and a feeling of impending doom.  On examination  he appears anxious  his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  and his heart rate is 100 bpm. An initial ECG shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads V1-V4  indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  This case reflects the demographic and disease trends accurately as African American men above 60 years with a smoking history and uncontrolled risk factors like hypertension  elevated LDL levels  and poor dietary habits have a high risk for developing acute myocardial infarction. This case serves to emphasize the importance of heart-healthy lifestyle changes  vigilant risk factor management  and the presentation and management of an acute myocardial infarction.

Case Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Female Patient With Diabetes  Patient Information:  Name: Martha Johnson Age: 58-year-old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Secretary Residence: Urban area  Past Medical History:  1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago and managed with Metformin. 2. Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with Lisinopril. 3. Hypercholesterolemia  managed with Atorvastatin 4. No previous history of heart disease. 5. Father deceased to myocardial infarction at the age of 62. 6. No history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption.  Key Complaints:  Ms. Johnson presented to the Emergency Department reporting sudden onset  severe  pressure like chest discomfort radiating to the left arm and jaw. The discomfort has lasted for the past 3 hours. She also reported associated symptoms  including shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating but denied any dizziness or fainting episodes. She did not note any recent emotional stress or strenuous physical activity aside from her usual daily chores.  On examination  she was found to be pale  anxiously clutching her chest  visibly sweating with a radial pulse rate of 90/min  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate 22/min. The rest of the physical exam was within normal limits.  This case report is a representative example  considering that acute myocardial infarction (AMI) is common in individuals aged 40-70 years  with a relatively higher risk in men  but the case incidence equalizes in women after menopause. Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia are identified risk factors for AMI. It is noted that women  in comparison to men  more frequently report non-chest-pain-associated symptoms during an AMI. Clinical symptoms of AMI  such as chest pain radiating to the arm and jaw  shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating  are core to this case because rapid recognition leads to timely intervention  reducing mortality and morbidity associated with the disease.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. Miguel Rodriguez - Age: 58 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Factory Worker - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Residence: Urban - Lifestyle: Occasional Smoker  Minimal Exercise  High-fat Diet Intake  Patient History:  Mr. Rodriguez has a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) for which he takes metformin  Obesity (BMI 30)  and Hypertension controlled with amlodipine. His mother died in her 60s due to myocardial infarction. His father had a stroke in his late 70s.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Rodriguez arrived at the ER with chief complaints of sudden-onset  severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm  persisting for the last two hours. The pain was associated with shortness of breath  profuse sweating  nausea  and a fear of impending doom.  Rationale:  This scenario represents a typical acute myocardial infarction (AMI) case. The patient represents a population commonly affected by AMI: Hispanic males  late middle-age  with controllable but significant risk factors  including hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Such factors heighten the risk for AMI  aligning with studies showing AMI patients often have multiple concordant conditions.  The case presents the common AMI symptoms—chest pain  shortness of breath  and nausea  and highlights some less common ones  like radiating pain and a fear of impending doom  which can be crucial in differentiating AMI from other conditions.   The case can act as a facilitator to discuss pathophysiology  risk factors  prevention strategies  disease progression  and immediate intervention needs related to acute myocardial infarctions.   References:   - Virani  S. S.  Alonso  A.  Aparicio  H. J.  Benjamin  E. J.  Bittencourt  M. S.  Bullard  K. M.  ...  & Tsao  C. W. (2021). Heart disease and stroke statistics—2021 update: a report from the American Heart Association. Circulation  143(8)  e254-e743. - Khera  A.  McGuire  D. K.  Murphy  S. A.  Stanek  H. G.  Das  S. R.  Vongpatanasin  W.  ... & de Lemos  J. A. (2005). Race and gender differences in C-reactive protein levels. Journal of the American College of Cardiology  46(3)  464-469.  - Sedgwick  J. E.  & Pearce  K. A. (2020). Risk Factors for Acute Myocardial Infarction in Latinos: A Systematic Review. Journal of cardiovascular translational research  13(6)  960-971.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe  Age: 63  Race: Caucasian  Gender: Male  Occupation: Electrician.  Past Medical History:   John Doe was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  for which he takes Metformin. He is also diagnosed with hypertension 4 years back  being managed with Lisinopril. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking two years ago  after a brief ischemic stroke with no persistent deficits. He hasn't been clinically diagnosed with hyperlipidemia but lacks regular health check-ups.   Key Complaints:  John Doe presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sustained chest pain that started an hour ago while he was at his morning work-shift. The pain is of sudden onset  constricting in nature  radiating to his left arm and neck. It is not alleviated by rest and is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating.  Discussion Notes:  The case represents a typical demographic of Caucasian male in his late sixties suffering from a potential acute myocardial infarction (AMI)  given his age  sex  race  and risk factors; including type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  smoking history  and possible hyperlipidemia. Study shows that Caucasians are more impacted by AMI incidence than any other racial group. Males are also more likely than females to experience AMI  especially in their mid-sixties.   Patient's history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and possible hyperlipidemia fits with the main risk factors of AMI. His symptoms represent classic signs of AMI: chest pain (typically radiating  constricting  not relieved by rest)  shortness of breath  nausea  and excessive sweating.   The acuity and severity of the symptoms including the context (occurrence during activity) point towards a severe case of possible myocardial infarction. Because Mr. Doe is high-risk (because of combined risk factors) and symptomatic  it warrants quick diagnosis and intervention to minimize heart muscle damage and improve the prognosis.   References: 1. Dharmarajan K  Wang Y  Lin Z  et al. Association of Changing Hospital Readmission Rates With Mortality Rates After Hospital Discharge. JAMA. 2017;318(3):270–278.  2. Krumholz HM  Normand ST  Wang Y. Trends in hospitalizations and outcomes for acute cardiovascular disease and stroke  1999-2011. Circulation. 2014;130(12):966–975.  3. CDC. Million Hearts: strategies to reduce the prevalence of leading cardiovascular disease risk factors. United States  2011. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2011;60(36):1248–125

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic  Residential area: Rural United States  Past Medical History 1. Hypertension - Diagnosed 12 years ago  irregularly taking prescribed anti-hypertensive medication. 2. Hyperlipidemia - Diagnosed 10 years ago  prescribed statins but often forgets to take them 3. Smoking: 40-pack year history; quit 5 years ago. 4. No known family history of heart disease. 5. No history of Diabetes Mellitus. 6. Lifestyle: Sedentary with low physical activity.  Key Complaints Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with severe  crushing chest pain that started about an hour ago while he was gardening. The chest pain radiated to his left arm and jaw. He also reported shortness of breath  light-headedness  nausea  and profuse sweating. He graded the pain 8/10  unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerin taken at home.  NOTE: This case represents a common presentation for Acute Myocardial Infarction based on major risk factors such as age  male gender  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. However  it is important for students to understand that Acute Myocardial Infarction can present in various ways across different ages  genders  and races. Additionally  symptom presentation might also vary among individuals (e.g.  women and diabetics might present with atypical symptoms).

Patient Case: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: - Name: John Doe (pseudonym) - Age: 60 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired teacher - Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: John has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus type II  and obesity. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago). His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  including his father who had a heart attack at the age of 55.   For his conditions  John has been prescribed with Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His compliance with medications has been variable due to a combination of forgetfulness and financial constraints.  Key Complaints: John presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with central  crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm which started approximately one hour ago while he was sitting in his chair after dinner. The pain is constant  non-remitting and rated 9/10. It is accompanied by dyspnea  nausea  light-headedness and diaphoresis.   He took one dose of his spouse’s nitroglycerin approximately 30 minutes before arrival at the ED with no relief. He states that he has never experienced pain like this before  describing it as a sense of pressure and squeezing in his chest. He denies having cough  fever  chills  gastrointestinal upset or recent trauma.  Given the patient's risk factors (age  male sex  family history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and former smoker)  clinical presentation (chest pain with radiation  nausea  diaphoresis  and non-response to nitroglycerin)  a differential diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is highly suspected. He is subsequently rushed to the cath lab for an emergent angiogram.  Note: Myocardial infarctions are most common in older adults  with the average age at diagnosis being about 64.5 years for men and 72.3 years for women. Caucasians and African-Americans have the highest rates of heart disease  followed by Hispanics and Asians. Risk factors include a history of hypertension  diabetes  obesity  hyperlipidemia  smoking  male sex  and family history of heart disease. This case is aligned with the typical patient demographics and risk factors found in literature.  Furthermore  the purpose of this case study is to enable medical students to identify symptoms of acute myocardial infarction and understand the importance of timely management to save myocardial tissue and prevent extensive heart damage. It will also give insights into patient’s compliance challenges with medication.

Case Study – Acute Myocardial Infarction  Demographics Identification: Patient is a 66-year-old African American male. He is a former mechanic  now retired. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children and three grandchildren.   Past Medical History: The patient has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that is fairly controlled with Metformin. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history but quit smoking 10 years ago due to worsening COPD. He has a 10-year history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril. He also has a documented previous episode of TIA with no residual deficits.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of on/off moderate to severe chest pain for the last 24 hours. Pain is described as “squeezing sensation” radiating from his chest to his left arm and up towards his neck. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  dizziness  nausea  and profuse sweating. He states that the symptoms started abruptly while he was doing yard work and did not completely resolve with rest. Symptoms have been worsening over the past few hours.  Ethnicity and Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI): Statistically  African Americans have a higher risk and earlier onset of AMI compared to Caucasians due to higher rates of hypertension  diabetes  and obesity. This case study reflects this demographic trend and emphasizes the importance of aggressive risk factor management in African American patients over 60.  Diabetes and AMI: The presence of diabetes in a patient raises the risk of AMI and other cardiovascular diseases significantly due to the pro-atherogenic state it causes. This creates an increased risk for plaque build-up in the coronary arteries  thus serving as a significant risk factor for AMI.  Hypertension and AMI: Long-standing hypertension can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy and systolic and diastolic heart failure  thereby increasing the patient's risk for AMI.  Previous TIA and AMI: A history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) can also be a potent predictor of subsequent AMI. TIAs indicate a pre-existing condition of the atherosclerotic disease  which also increases the risk for AMI.  Smoking and AMI: Although this patient has quit smoking  his significant smoking history continues to contribute to his risk for heart disease  as the damaging effects on blood vessels can persist for many years after cessation.  Obesity and AMI: Although not explicitly mentioned in this case  obesity is another risk factor often associated with AMI. It is reasonably common  especially in patients with other comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension  further increasing the risk of AMI.

Case Report – Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Demographics:  - Name: John Doe - Age: 62 - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired police officer - Marital Status: Married - Ethnicity: African American  relevant as literature points out they experience higher incidents of coronary artery. - Lifestyle: Former smoker  quit 10 years ago  occasional alcohol use  and admits to a diet high in processed and fast foods. - Geographical Location: Urban setting  lives in a single-family home.  Past Medical History (PMH):  - Hypertension diagnosed at age 50  controlled with lisinopril  - Type 2 diabetes diagnosed at age 58  managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications - Mom died from heart disease at 70 and his dad had a stroke in his late 60s  highlighting a family lineage with cardiovascular disease. - No known drug allergies. - Annual check-ups with primary care physician.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presents to the Emergency Room (ER) with severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  which started around 3 hours ago at rest. He tried to ignore it initially  thinking it was gastric reflux. As the pain persists  he started sweating profusely and experienced shortness of breath. The pain didn’t alleviate with rest  increasing his concern. Over-the-counter antacids provided no relief  either. He rates his pain as 8/10 on a subjective pain scale.   Physical Examination upon Admission:  - BP: 160/90 mmHg - Heart Rate: 95 bpm - Temperature: 37.2 °C (98.9 °F) - Respiratory Rate: 22 bpm - Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air  - Body Mass Index: 28.5 (overweight) - On examination: Looks anxious  in distress  clammy skin. - Cardiovascular examination: S1  S2 sounds present  no added sounds. - Chest: Clear to auscultation  no wheezes or crackles. - Abdomen: Soft  non-tender. - There is no noticeable peripheral edema on the lower limbs.  This case is designed to represent common clinical realities of coronary artery disease in underserved populations. The factors in this case such as hypertension  diabetes  obesity  poor diet  family history and the ethnicity of the patient are noted as high risk factors for acute myocardial infarction.  References:   - Writing Case Studies: A Manual  (n.d). National Center for Professional   & Research Ethics.    - Virani SS  Alonso A  Benjamin EJ  et al. Heart disease and stroke statistics—2020 update: a report from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2020;141(9):e139-e596.

Case Study: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Profile  Name: Mr. John Ethridge Age: 61 years Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Long-distance truck driver Location: Urban  Midwest Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History: Mr. Ethridge has been diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  for which he’s under daily medications containing an ACE inhibitor  statin  and metformin. He also has a 30-pack year history of smoking and is obese with a BMI of 32. His mother died of a myocardial infarction at age 70.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Ethridge came to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain that had started about 4 hours ago. The pain was severe  described as heavy and radiating to his left arm and neck. It was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and a feeling of cold sweat. He also reported feeling light-headed. He has never had pain like this before and was brought to the hospital by his neighbor. He noted that he felt the discomfort after lifting heavy boxes at home. He does not exercise regularly  reporting that his work involves long periods of sitting.  Justification:   The case report presented focuses on Mr. Ethridge  a 61 year-old African American traveling truck driver based in the Midwest. This demographic representation was carefully chosen to highlight the increased risk of heart disease among African American males aged 45-64  as found in literature. Additionally  Mr. Ethridge’s occupation and lifestyle represent sedentary behavior  which further increases his risk. His socioeconomic status is alluded to by his job and his insurance type (Medicare)  signaling potential healthcare access issues. His personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and smoking  along with the familial history of heart disease  are all significant risk factors for acute myocardial infarction. The case has been designed to encourage students to think critically and holistically about both modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Information: Gender: Male Age: 59 years  Occupation: Construction Worker   Demographics: The patient is an African American male living in an underserved urban area in Chicago  USA. He's a divorcee living with his grown-up children. A graduate  he is a front-line construction worker with a history of cigarette smoking of 30 pack-years.  Medical History: He has a documented history of hypertension which has been mildly controlled with medication (Metoprolol 50mg once daily) for the past 7 years. He has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus controlled by Metformin 500mg twice daily for 3 years. He also suffers from moderate obesity  with a BMI of 33.  Key Complaints:  1. The patient reports the sudden onset of severe pain in the center of his chest that started about an hour ago. He describes it as crushing in nature and radiating to the left jaw and shoulder.   2. He reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  an increasing cold sweat and a sense of feeling extremely weak.   3. He experiences exacerbations of the pain on minimal exertion and relief momentarily on rest but the pain continues to persist.   4. He has reported no episodes of vomiting  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. The symptoms have not improved with his usual antacids.  Patient notes: The patient has not been compliant with regular check-ups especially during the COVID-19 pandemic. He reports increased stress levels due to work-related pressure and financial strain over the past few months. This has led to an increase in his smoking frequency. He has a family history of heart diseases  his father passed away due to a heart attack at age 62.  This case is designed to present a typical high-risk individual for an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  taking into account factors such as smoking behavior  stressful lifestyle  family history  non-compliance with medical advice  African American ethnicity  and location in an urban setting. The focus is given to common signs and symptoms of AMI  which require immediate medical attention. The complications of AMI  various treatment modalities  and long term management can be further discussed as the case progresses.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker  born and raised in Texas  living with his wife who takes on the role of caregiver.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez is a known case of long-standing Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia  all of which have been controlled with oral medications. He is also a smoker  with a history of 40 pack-years  and is occasionally consuming alcohol on social gatherings. His family history reveals his father died at the age of 69 due to a heart attack.  Key Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain  radiating to his left arm  about 2 hours back. The pain was severe  squeezing in nature  and was accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of impending doom. There was no history of trauma or injury. On admission  he appears pale  sweating  and in evident distress.  Rationale for the Case:  The prevalence of acute myocardial infraction is quite significant in older adults especially those with conditions like Diabetes  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia  which are common in the Hispanic population like Mr. Rodriguez. These risk factors coupled with his smoking history makes Mr. Rodriguez an appropriate patient scenario to discuss the acute presentation  examination  and management of a patient with a suspected acute myocardial infarction. The case promotes understanding of the pathophysiology  differential diagnosis  and principles of treatment for this commonly seen cardiac emergency.

Patient Case: Acute Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. Smith - Age: 62 years old  - Sex: Male - Race/Ethnicity: African American  - Occupation: Retired  previous profession was stressful and sedentary (e.g.  attorney) - Lifestyle: Smokes a pack of cigarettes daily since he was 18 and generally inactive with a diet high in saturated fats and sodium.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension  diagnosed 8 years ago - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled by medication - Hyperlipidemia - Family history of heart disease (Father died at the age of 66 from a heart attack)  Key Presenting Complaints: - Severe and crushing chest pain that started an hour ago  radiating to his left arm and jaw - Shortness of breath - Sweating excessively - Feelings of indigestion or heartburn - Fatigue and lightheadedness  Recent History: - Over the past few months  Mr. Smith has noticed he was getting tired easily with slight exertion  which he decided to neglect and ascribed it to ‘old age’.  (Note: This case reflects reported data where acute myocardial infarctions are more common in older males and African Americans. Risk factors often include hypertension  smoking  diabetes  a sedentary lifestyle  and a diet high in saturated fat and sodium. It is also worth noting that symptoms can sometimes be mistaken for less severe conditions such as indigestion.)

Title: Acute Myocardial Infarction in a Middle-aged Female Patient  Patient Presentation:  A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that started 3 hours ago. The patient describes the pain as a crushing sensation that radiates to her left arm and jaw. The discomfort is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. She also reports experiencing shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating.   Patient Demographics:   The patient is of African-American descent  a demographic widely represented in heart disease cases within the United States. She is an English professor and lives with her two teenage children in a suburban neighborhood. She does not report any alcohol or illicit drug use. She does not smoke but mentions having secondhand smoke exposure at her previous job in a restaurant where she worked for 10 years.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed five years ago for which she takes Lisinopril daily. She was also diagnosed with high cholesterol three years ago and takes Atorvastatin. She is obese (BMI 30.5) with a family history of premature coronary artery disease (CAD) - her father had a myocardial infarction at age 55. She was also previously advised to maintain a healthy diet and regular exercise  but she struggled due to her busy schedules and financial issues.  Currently  the patient reports poor medication adherence citing forgetfulness due to her busy daily schedules.  Key Medical Issues:  1. Severe chest pain radiating to left arm and jaw not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. 2. Co-existing conditions include hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and family history of premature CAD. 3. The patient reports poor medication adherence.  Learning Objectives:  1. Recognize the signs and symptoms of acute myocardial infarction (MI). 2. Identify the risk factors associated with myocardial infarction. 3. Understand the role of social determinants of health in the management of chronic illnesses. 4. Improving medication adherence as a part of chronic disease management strategies. 5. Learn about the importance of preventative strategies in patients at high risk of MI.   This case explores an instance of heart disease in a patient with multiple pathways for intervention and emphasizes on personalizing treatment strategies considering the patient's lifestyle  circumstances  and capacity to self-manage.

Case Report – Acute Myocardial Infarction   Patient Information: Patient Name: Marcus Thompson  Age: 59 years old  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: African American   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of uncontrolled Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His family history includes his father  who died of a myocardial infarction at 62  and has a brother with coronary artery disease. He is  unfortunately  a 30-pack-year smoker who attempts but struggles to quit smoking. He doesn't exercise often and also struggles with maintaining a healthy diet. Moreover  he is obese with a BMI of 31.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Thompson presented to the ED with severe  crushing central chest pain of sudden onset about an hour post completion of his routine yard work. He describes the pain as constant and reports it radiating to the left arm and up to his jaw. He rates it as a 10/10 on a pain scale and mentions it was not relieved by rest or after taking his usual nitroglycerin. He also reports associated symptoms including  sweating  nausea  and shortness of breath.   This mock case was constructed keeping in mind the high prevalence of Acute Myocardial Infarction in older males especially those of African-American ethnicity as shown in literature. Risk factors reflected in this case include uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  smoking  obesity  lack of physical activity  poor diet  and strong family history  all of which are known contributors to coronary artery disease and subsequent myocardial infarction.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson  who is a retired school teacher. He lives with his wife and is a non-smoker. He is known in the community for his active lifestyle despite his age  often seen gardening  and going for walks.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension  for which he takes medication. His cholesterol levels were deemed borderline high in his last annual check-up. His father had died due to a sudden cardiac event at the age of 70  and his mother was diabetic as well. He does not have any known food or drug allergies.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson was brought to the emergency department after he collapsed while gardening. His wife confirmed that he complained of a severe  crushing chest pain that radiated to his left arm  which was followed by lightheadedness  sweating  and shortness of breath. He denied any prior episodes of similar symptoms. He does not remember losing consciousness  and there were no convulsions witnessed. He did not have any symptoms of indigestion or heartburn  no bowel or bladder complaints. He confirms adhering to his hypertension medication and denied taking any new over-the-counter drugs.  With the given data and careful consideration of the demographic representation based on literature (African Americans have a higher risk of myocardial infarction particularly at an older age  hypertensives  males and those with a family history)  the working diagnosis would be acute myocardial infarction in consideration of the patient's age  race  male gender  familial predisposition  personal medical history  and clinical symptoms.   The focus of the management session of this clinical case would be to provide a comprehensive cardiovascular examination  order appropriate investigations  discuss potential interventions  and develop a holistic long-term management plan including lifestyle modifications.

Patient Information:   Long-Distance Trucker  Mr. John Edwards  African-American Male  Age: 62 years old.   Present complaints:  Mr. Edwards had been experiencing intermittent chest pain early in the morning for the past week  usually during his morning routines. The pain was located centrally in his chest  described as a heavy squeezing sensation  occasionally spreading to his left arm and neck. The uncomfortable feeling would last around 10-15 minutes and resolve spontaneously but returned on exertion.  Emergency Room Encounter: Mr. Edwards called 911 after a severe episode of pain that lasted more than 30 minutes and was associated with sweating and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension - for the past 12 years  under treatment. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. 3. Smoker - 20 cigarettes a day for 30 years. 4. Obesity - Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31.  Family History:  1. Father had a fatal myocardial infarction at age 65. 2. Younger sister diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Review of Systems:  Negative except for the intermittent chest pain and occasional exertional dyspnea over the past week.  Social History:  Mr. Edwards lives alone. He has a job as a long-distance truck driver which involves long hours of sedentary travel. His smoking habit of 30 years has recently been accompanied by an increase in daily alcohol consumption. He does not exercise due to his sedentary job and reports a diet high in salt and fat due to convenient fast food options on the road.  Physical Examination: Patient appeared uncomfortable and sweating profusely.  - BMI: 31  BP: 160/100 mmHg  Pulse: 105 beats per minute. - Cardiac auscultation: Tachycardic with no audible murmurs  rubs  or gallops. - Respiratory system: Clear to auscultation. - Abdominal Examination: Soft  non-tender  no hepato-splenomegaly. - Extremities: No pedal edema.  Initial diagnosis to explore:  Acute myocardial infarction  To confirm diagnosis  immediate electrocardiogram and cardiac biomarkers assay should be considered. Further management with a cardiology consult is desired. Also  a comprehensive strategy targeting his lifestyle choices  co-morbidities  and risk factors would be beneficial.

Case Report: Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  Patient Demographics: Name: Alex Smith Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian-American Occupation: Truck Driver Residence: Rural area of Kentucky  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (controlled with Losartan 50mg daily) - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily) - Hypercholesterolemia (currently on Atorvastatin 20mg daily) - Smoker for 30 years (~1 pack/day) with ongoing attempts to quit using nicotine patches and gum - Family history of causative cardiac diseases  with a father and brother who experienced myocardial infarctions in their early 60s.  Key Complaints/Presentation: Mr. Smith presented to the ER with central  crushing chest pain (7/10) that started approximately 45 minutes before his arrival. The pain radiated to his left arm and was associated with sweating and shortness of breath. He denied any nausea  vomiting or dizziness. He noted that the pain occurred while he was engaged in heavy lifting at his job and didn't subside with rest.  This case scenario encapsulates key demographic points from literature regarding acute myocardial infarction. AMI has been shown to be prevalent in males  with higher frequency in those over the age of 60  and who have a significant cardiac risk profile including smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and diabetes. Occupation involving strenuous activity and residence in a rural area may reflect on delayed presentation and possible risk factors  while family history completion represents significant genetic predisposition often seen with this condition.

Case Subject: Mr. Frank Johnson  Demographics:  Mr. Johnson is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  currently retired. He used to work as an accountant and lives in the suburbs with his wife.
